headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for standing by. Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Amazon.com Q4 2015 Financial Results Teleconference. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks, I will be turning the call over to the Director of Invest
componenttext:
Thank you for standing by. Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Amazon.com Q4 2015 Financial Results Teleconference. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. 
For opening remarks, I will be turning the call over to the Director of Investor Relations, Phil Hardin. Please go ahead.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to our Q4 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. Joining us today is Brian Olsavsky, our CFO. We will be available for questions after our prepared remarks. The following discussion and responses to your questions reflects management's
componenttext:
Hello, and welcome to our Q4 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. Joining us today is Brian Olsavsky, our CFO. We will be available for questions after our prepared remarks. The following discussion and responses to your questions reflects management's views as of today, January 28, 2016, only and will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially. Additional information about factors that could potentially impact our financial result is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, including our most recent Annual Report on Form 10-K. 
As you listen to today's conference call, we encourage you to have our press release in front of you, which includes our financial results as well as metrics and commentary on the quarter. 
During this call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures in our press release, slides accompanying this webcast and our filings with the SEC, each of which is posted on our IR website. You will find additional disclosures regarding these non-GAAP measures, including reconciliations of these measures with comparable GAAP measures. Finally, unless otherwise stated, all comparisons in this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2014. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Brian.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Phil. I'll begin with comments on our fourth quarter financial results. Trailing 12-month operating cash flow increased 74% to $11.9 billion. Trailing 12-month free cash flow increased to $7.3 billion, up from $1.9 billion. Trailing 12-month free
componenttext:
Thanks, Phil. I'll begin with comments on our fourth quarter financial results. Trailing 12-month operating cash flow increased 74% to $11.9 billion. Trailing 12-month free cash flow increased to $7.3 billion, up from $1.9 billion. Trailing 12-month free cash flow, less lease principal repayments increased to $4.7 billion, up from $529 million. Trailing 12-month free cash flow less finance lease principal repayments and assets acquired under capital leases increased to $2.5 billion, up from an outflow of $2.2 billion. Trailing 12-month capital expenditures were $4.6 billion. Capital expenditures does not include the impact of property and equipment acquired under capital and finance lease obligations. These capital expenditures and capital leases reflect additional investments in support of continued business growth due to investments in technology infrastructure, the majority of which is to support AWS and additional capacity to support our fulfillment operations. The combination of common stock and stock-based awards outstanding was 490 million shares compared with 483 million 1 year ago. 
Worldwide revenue increased 22% to $35.7 billion or 26%, excluding the $1.2 billion unfavorable impact from year-over-year changes in foreign exchange. Worldwide paid unit growth was 26%. Worldwide active customer accounts were approximately 304 million. Excluding customers who only had 3 orders in the preceding 12-month period, worldwide active customer accounts were approximately 280 million, up from approximately 254 million in the comparable prior-year period. Worldwide paid prime members increased 51% year-over-year. Worldwide seller units represented 47% of paid units. Performance by Amazon or FBA units represent nearly 50% of seller units. Worldwide active Amazon Web Services customers exceeded 1 million. 
Now I'll discuss operating expenses, excluding stock-based compensation. Cost of sales was $24.3 billion or 68.1% of revenue compared with 70.5%. Fulfillment, marketing, technology and content and G&A combined was $9.7 billion or 27.1% of sales, up approximately 100 basis points year-over-year. Fulfillment was $4.4 billion or 12.3% of revenue compared with 11.3%. Tech and content was $3.2 billion or 9% of revenue compared with 8.2%. Marketing was $1.7 billion or 4.8% of revenue compared with 5.1%. 
Now I'll talk about our segment results. As a reminder, in the first quarter, we changed our reportable segments to report North America, international and Amazon Web Services. Consistent with prior periods, we do not allocate to our segments our stock-based compensation or the other operating expense line item. In the North America segment, revenue grew 24% to $21.5 billion. Media revenue grew 11% to $3.9 billion or 12%, excluding foreign exchange. EGM revenue grew 28% to $17.3 billion. North America segment operating income was $1 billion, a 4.7% operating margin, compared with $733 million in the prior year period. North America segment operating income includes $6 million of favorable impact from foreign exchange. In the international segment, revenue grew 12% to $11.8 billion. Excluding the $1.1 billion year-over-year unfavorable foreign exchange impact, revenue growth was 22%. Media revenue decreased 3% to $3.3 billion or increased 5%, excluding foreign exchange. EGM revenue grew 19% to $8.5 billion or 31%, excluding foreign exchange. International segment operating income was $60 million compared with $65 million in the prior year. International segment operating income includes $47 million of unfavorable impact from foreign exchange. In the Amazon Web Services segment, revenue grew 69% to $2.4 billion. Amazon Web Services segment operating income was $687 million, a 28.5% operating margin, compared with $240 million in the prior year period. AWS segment operating income includes $60 million of favorable impact from foreign exchange. Consolidated segment operating income was $1.8 billion or 4.9% of revenue, up approximately 140 basis points year-over-year. CSOI includes $20 million of favorable impact from foreign exchange. Unlike CSOI, our GAAP operating income includes stock-based compensation expense and other operating expense. GAAP operating income grew 88% to $1.1 billion. Our income tax expense was $453 million. GAAP net income was $482 million or $1 per diluted share compared with a net income of $214 million and $0.45 per diluted share. 
Now I'll discuss the full year results. Revenue increased 20% to $107 billion or 26%, excluding year-over-year changes in foreign exchange. North America revenue grew 25% to $63.7 billion or 26%, excluding year-over-year changes in foreign exchange. International revenue grew 6% to $35.4 billion or 21%, excluding year-over-year changes in foreign exchange. Excluding year-over-year changes in foreign exchange, Germany revenue grew 18%, Japan revenue grew 19% and U.K. revenue grew 16%. AWS revenue grew 70% to $7.9 billion. Consolidated segment operating income was $4.5 billion or 4.2% of revenue, up approximately 220 basis points year-over-year. CSOI includes $16 million of favorable impact from foreign exchange. GAAP operating income was $2.2 billion compared with $178 million in the prior year. 
Turning to the balance sheet. Cash and marketable securities increased $2.4 billion year-over-year to $19.8 billion. Inventory increased 23% to $10.2 billion and inventory turns were 8.5, down from 8.6 turns a year ago as we expanded selection improved in stock levels and introduced new product categories. Accounts payable increased 24% to $20.4 billion and accounts payable days increased to 77 from 73 in the prior year. 
I'll conclude my portion of today's call with guidance. Incorporated into our guidance are the order trends that we've seen to date and what we believe today to be perfectly conservative assumptions. Our results are inherently unpredictable and may be materially affected by many factors, including a high level of uncertainty surrounding exchange rate fluctuations as well as the global economy and customer spending. It's not possible to accurately predict demand, and therefore, our actual results could differ materially from our guidance. As we described in more detail in our public filings, issues such as settling intercompany balances and foreign currencies among our subsidiaries, unfavorable resolution of legal matters and changes to our effective tax rate can all have a material effect on guidance. Our guidance further assumes that we don't conclude any additional business acquisitions, investments, restructurings or legal settlements recording any further revisions to stock-based compensation estimates and that foreign exchange rates remain approximately where they've been recently. 
For Q1 2016, we expect net sales to be between $26.5 billion and $29 billion or growth of between 17% and 28%. This guidance anticipates approximately 130 basis points of unfavorable impact from foreign exchange rates. GAAP operating income to be between $100 million and $700 million compared with $255 million in the first quarter 2015. This includes approximately $600 million for stock-based compensation and other operating expenses net. We anticipate consolidated segment operating income, which excludes stock-based compensation and other operating expense net, to be between $700 million and $1.3 billion compared with $706 million in the first quarter of 2015. 
We are grateful to our customers and remain heads down focused on driving better customer experience. We believe putting customers first is the only reliable way to create lasting value for shareholders. Thanks. And with that, Phil, let's move on to questions.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Brian. Let's move on to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, will you please remind our listeners how to initiate a question?
componenttext: Great. Thanks, Brian. Let's move on to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, will you please remind our listeners how to initiate a question?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from analyst Stephen Ju with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from analyst Stephen Ju with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Brian, I think in the past you've given some indication as to what usage growth may be at AWS. I was wondering if you have an update for that in the fourth quarter. And secondarily, is there any way to characterize what the pricing environment is right
componenttext: So Brian, I think in the past you've given some indication as to what usage growth may be at AWS. I was wondering if you have an update for that in the fourth quarter. And secondarily, is there any way to characterize what the pricing environment is right now for AWS as well?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't have a usage growth number for you. I will say we're -- it's been very strong and the AWS revenue is on a -- just sort of a $10 billion run rate at the end of Q4. First, pricing as concerned, we had a price reduction in January for our ECT ser
componenttext: No, I don't have a usage growth number for you. I will say we're -- it's been very strong and the AWS revenue is on a -- just sort of a $10 billion run rate at the end of Q4. First, pricing as concerned, we had a price reduction in January for our ECT services. It was our 51st price reduction since we launched AWS years ago. And generally, what we find is that price is important, but so is speed and agility for customers and the ability to deliver services and features that are beneficial to them. I will point out that we added 722 new features and services in 2015, and that was up 40% year-over-year. So we feel we have a lead in the space and we don't taken for granted and we want to serve customers better each year.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from analyst Jason Helfstein with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question is from analyst Jason Helfstein with Oppenheimer.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about the dynamics in the fourth quarter e-commerce, particularly in the U.S.? Did we see more aggressive promotional activity? And maybe talk about how you try to work that to continue to drive the prime number of numbers going
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about the dynamics in the fourth quarter e-commerce, particularly in the U.S.? Did we see more aggressive promotional activity? And maybe talk about how you try to work that to continue to drive the prime number of numbers going forward?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, what I can say is our approach to pricing has not changed, and [indiscernible], we did everything we could to have the best prices available for customers and in stock in time for the holiday. Another dynamic of Q4 was that it was a huge FBA q
componenttext: Sure. Well, what I can say is our approach to pricing has not changed, and [indiscernible], we did everything we could to have the best prices available for customers and in stock in time for the holiday. Another dynamic of Q4 was that it was a huge FBA quarter. Nearly 50% of our third-party units were FBA and our third-party units were also up to 47% of our paid units. It's up 400 basis points year-over-year. So a really strong quarter for our FBA sellers using our FBA services. It did put a lot of demand on our warehouses and we were followed. It was a very busy quarter and it did increase some of our cost as a result, primarily in the U.S. But a very strong quarter for FBA. It exceeded even our expectations.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perhaps how you were able to integrate that into holiday promotions?
componenttext: Perhaps how you were able to integrate that into holiday promotions?

componenttext: Sure. Just any additional color around Prime and how you were able to integrate that into holiday promotions.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing specific. I will say one interesting enhancement this year was our Prime Now service, which allowed people to order in selected markets up til 11:59 on New Year's -- excuse me, Christmas eve. So that was a valuable service to many late shoppers, l
componenttext: Nothing specific. I will say one interesting enhancement this year was our Prime Now service, which allowed people to order in selected markets up til 11:59 on New Year's -- excuse me, Christmas eve. So that was a valuable service to many late shoppers, last minute shoppers.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Aram Rubinson with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Aram Rubinson with Wolfe Research.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions, both on the logistics side. It seems pretty clear that you guys are trafficking in some old world assets like truck trailers and ship lanes and airfield. Can you help give us a sense just to maybe what we're trying to accomplish with that i
componenttext: Two questions, both on the logistics side. It seems pretty clear that you guys are trafficking in some old world assets like truck trailers and ship lanes and airfield. Can you help give us a sense just to maybe what we're trying to accomplish with that if it's defensive to protector your service to existing customers or if you're looking to maybe start new businesses with those assets.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say that what we found is an order to properly serve our customers at peak, we've needed to add more of our own logistics to supplement our existing partners. That's not meant to replace them. And those carriers are just no longer able to handle a
componenttext: I would say that what we found is an order to properly serve our customers at peak, we've needed to add more of our own logistics to supplement our existing partners. That's not meant to replace them. And those carriers are just no longer able to handle all of our capacity that we need at peak. They're been and continue to be great partners, and we look forward to working with them in the future. It's just we've had to add some resources on our own. You mentioned trucks. The Amazon trucks, we did invest in those this past year. We use those primarily for movement between our warehouses and our sort centers.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2. The first one is just on gross margins. I think they were down by 200 basis points sequentially. It's the biggest fall in the fourth quarter in quite some time. Anything you caught there? Is it devices? Or more sortation centers? Is there anythi
componenttext: I have 2. The first one is just on gross margins. I think they were down by 200 basis points sequentially. It's the biggest fall in the fourth quarter in quite some time. Anything you caught there? Is it devices? Or more sortation centers? Is there anything pressuring gross margins we should think about in the fourth quarter? And then on the fulfillment line, you mentioned FBA being a big driver of the growth in the fulfillment cost. Anything else you would call out leading to incremental fulfillment cost, maybe India or something else?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. And again, keep in mind that the fulfillment as a percent of revenue is impacted by the calculation of FBA revenue being a net number as opposed to a full revenue number. But our fulfillment cost per unit actually decrease year-over-year. It's just we
componenttext: No. And again, keep in mind that the fulfillment as a percent of revenue is impacted by the calculation of FBA revenue being a net number as opposed to a full revenue number. But our fulfillment cost per unit actually decrease year-over-year. It's just we are now shipping more and more of our -- of the demand out of our warehouses because of the strength in retail and FBA. On gross margin, I would first caution you and say we encourage you to look at free cash flow, which was -- grew at a minimum $4 billion on each of the metrics that we point out and our profit, which was up 80% year-over-year. If you look sequentially, also keep in mind that in Q3, when it was up 5 basis points year-over-year, that was lapping the write-down of our Amazon phone inventory the prior year. So there's a little bit of noise in Q3 number. But generally, again, we're happy with the ability to service customers, the reactions of customers in Q4 and the bottom line results that we had.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Colin Sebastian with Baird Equity Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Colin Sebastian with Baird Equity Research.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: One follow-up and then another question. On the logistics and transportation side, I was curious if that's today just to supplement some of the other carriers, but more broadly our longer term, is there an ambition from the services side to perhaps provid
componenttext: One follow-up and then another question. On the logistics and transportation side, I was curious if that's today just to supplement some of the other carriers, but more broadly our longer term, is there an ambition from the services side to perhaps provide capacity to other companies. And then on the AWS margins, which I was just wondering if we should expect more leverage there going forward and whether Q1 -- whether that should demonstrate some seasonality versus what we've seen in terms of sequential growth in prior years.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me work backwards. Don't give guidance by segments. So I cannot really comment on AWS specifically in Q1. And then the operational improvements -- excuse me, the gross margin -- the operating margin year-over-year that we've seen in the AWB busi
componenttext: Sure. Let me work backwards. Don't give guidance by segments. So I cannot really comment on AWS specifically in Q1. And then the operational improvements -- excuse me, the gross margin -- the operating margin year-over-year that we've seen in the AWB business has been heavily driven by operating efficiencies, both purchase reductions, purchase prices and also efficiency in driving greater utilization of the assets that we have. So I'm very happy with that. Keep in mind that we did have -- although the year-over-year increase in capital expenditures and capital leases was not as great as we saw in 2013 to 2014, we did spend over $9 billion on those capital expenditures and capital lease obligations up from prior year it was -- excuse me.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question --

componenttext: Let me finish my answer to them, please. We grew in the $5 billion range in 2013 to $8.9 billion in 2014 and now, over $9 billion in 2015.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Innovative Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Innovative Evercore ISI.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a lot of headlines Amazon activity at Sundance. I was just hoping maybe you can expand with more on the video strategy and specifically are seeing an inflection and Prime usage and maybe just also on your streaming partners program, what the gener
componenttext: There's a lot of headlines Amazon activity at Sundance. I was just hoping maybe you can expand with more on the video strategy and specifically are seeing an inflection and Prime usage and maybe just also on your streaming partners program, what the general reception is like.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We're very thrilled with the customer response to Prime video. Again, when Prime video is used by our Prime members, it drives adoption and retention, higher free trial conversion rates and higher renewal rates for subscribers. So what we're encoura
componenttext: Sure. We're very thrilled with the customer response to Prime video. Again, when Prime video is used by our Prime members, it drives adoption and retention, higher free trial conversion rates and higher renewal rates for subscribers. So what we're encouraged by Q4 is that globally, we doubled the number of -- our Prime members doubled the number of viewing hours of the Prime video year-over-year. And internationally, we had twice as many Prime members streaming year-over-year. So very encouraged by the pickup and the response of customers. The other comment I would say about video is we're very happy with the Amazon Studios content, in particular, we had some great success in 2014 and 2015. As you probably know, Transparent has won multiple Golden Globes and Emmys, both for actors and for the show itself. [indiscernible] Jungle, which has won 2 Golden Globe Awards. So very pleased with the critical acclaim to the Amazon Studios content and we've got a lot of new content coming out this year. season 2, Bosch season 2. We're all looking forward to. In February, we will have Chirac, our first original movie we got to work with Spike Lee on, which won many critical -- made many critics best film flicks for 2015. That will be coming to Prime video in February.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to add, this is Phil. On your question about the streaming partners program, so that's our new over-the-top streaming subscription program for Prime members. We think it's a really convenient way for them to access additional content -- content from
componenttext: Just to add, this is Phil. On your question about the streaming partners program, so that's our new over-the-top streaming subscription program for Prime members. We think it's a really convenient way for them to access additional content -- content from sources like Showtime, Stars. It's really early so it's just out of the gate, but we've been very pleased with what we've seen so far.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things, please. Any callouts on the macro side? Efficiently, you called anything you can't things out anything this time. And then can you talk a little about Amazon business. I know there's a little bit of aligning the press release on it. It had was
componenttext: Two things, please. Any callouts on the macro side? Efficiently, you called anything you can't things out anything this time. And then can you talk a little about Amazon business. I know there's a little bit of aligning the press release on it. It had was a couple of years that any indications to the materiality of that, the kind of momentum it's gaining, the kind of traction it's gaining.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mark. No macroeconomic comments. Again, we feel we're very encouraged by the customer response for our offerings in Q4. Amazon business, yes, in April, you may remember we launched marketplace with specific features and benefits for businesses that
componenttext: Sure, Mark. No macroeconomic comments. Again, we feel we're very encouraged by the customer response for our offerings in Q4. Amazon business, yes, in April, you may remember we launched marketplace with specific features and benefits for businesses that Amazon business now serves more than 200,000 businesses from smaller organizations to Fortune 500 companies. So it's still early, but we're encouraged and we think we're creating some value, a lot of value for business customers.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mark may with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mark may with Citi.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on international retail business. I think you added well over $1 billion in revenue year-on-year in the quarter, but from a CSOI perspective, you really didn't see any improvement there. I'm sure there are a lot of different things going on. I'
componenttext: A question on international retail business. I think you added well over $1 billion in revenue year-on-year in the quarter, but from a CSOI perspective, you really didn't see any improvement there. I'm sure there are a lot of different things going on. I'm just wondering if you could unpack that a little bit and give us a sense of what profitability looks like maybe in some of your more mature established countries and regions relative to the investments we're making and other countries so that we can kind of get a better picture of what's actually going on under the hood there.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mark. We are very pleased by the international growth, 22% FX neutral was up 1,000 basis points year-over-year. We saw that the Prime growth, Prime membership growth was 50% -- excuse me, 51% globally, 47% in the U.S. means that the international Pr
componenttext: Sure, Mark. We are very pleased by the international growth, 22% FX neutral was up 1,000 basis points year-over-year. We saw that the Prime growth, Prime membership growth was 50% -- excuse me, 51% globally, 47% in the U.S. means that the international Prime programs growing at a faster clip than that. So very, very pleased with the uptick. We rolled out a lot of additional Prime features internationally as well this year from free same day to Prime Now to Prime Music and Prime Video in Japan to name a few. So very happy with that. But in general, if I step back, our investments in national are twofold. First, there's the Prime platform and all the features I just mentioned, including the fulfillment, adding more fulfillment resources to handle higher and higher retail volumes and very strong FBA program as well. And then the remainder -- the biggest other investment areas of the India and we like -- what's we continue to see, like what we see in India. In Q4, Amazon India was a top e-commerce site in India throughout the very busy Diwali shopping season, including the shopping season according to come score and sales by sellers in Q4 were greater than all of 2014 combined in Q4. So seeing great progress with downloads, innovations for sellers and customers alike, and we like the ramp there and we're continuing to invest in India.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things. Just first on the North America EGM growth. If you just talk about the 28% there and the detail on easier comp and whether there's any particular factors within that we should be thinking about and perhaps if there is an new weather and appare
componenttext: Two things. Just first on the North America EGM growth. If you just talk about the 28% there and the detail on easier comp and whether there's any particular factors within that we should be thinking about and perhaps if there is an new weather and apparel impact there. And then second, last quarter, and I don't want to miss quote you, but you said something along the lines are being able to invest as you like and also deliver good profit and the pendulum will swing as far as perhaps it has in the past. Is that statement and thoughts still hold as you head into '16?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me start with EGM. So EGM growth, North America EGM growth of 28% was actually also the highest in the last 4 years. So we're happy with that. The deceleration you're seeing, 700 basis points, is more a function of the Prime Day that we had in Q
componenttext: Sure. Let me start with EGM. So EGM growth, North America EGM growth of 28% was actually also the highest in the last 4 years. So we're happy with that. The deceleration you're seeing, 700 basis points, is more a function of the Prime Day that we had in Q3, if you remember. We didn't break it out by segment, but we said that Prime Day contributed 200 basis points to our Q3 run rate -- revenue growth rate. So sequentially, last year, in the North America EGM, we dropped from 31% to 27%. This year, it's 35% to 28%. So there is always generally a sequential drop in Q4. But certainly, very happy with that business and its role in Prime as well total customer satisfaction. Your other question, investments. Yes, we continue to have healthy investments, as we've stated, across the globe. To step back again on that, our general philosophy is we want to find things, businesses that customers love and can grow, be large, will provide strong financial returns and adorable, it can last for decades. We think Prime is that. We think the marketplace is that. We think AWS is that. And we're constantly looking for a fourth or fifth business that fits that criteria. So, but as we continue to invest primarily in, as I said, in Prime, the Prime platform, Prime features for customers, expansion for fulfillment capacity as we build out this for 26% [ph] unit growth in Q4 for instance and much greater FBA share. And not to mention all the investments in AWS. We're constantly looking for cost efficiencies in fixed and variable productivity. I think about the investments will have been flow over time, but our focus on cost reduction and improvement in customer experience will be constant.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. If I was wondering if you can give us a sense as we look at the slowing growth in AWS. Obviously still from an incredibly, incredibly high-level and still very strong growth there. But try and take that into contact with the growth in margins that
componenttext: Great. If I was wondering if you can give us a sense as we look at the slowing growth in AWS. Obviously still from an incredibly, incredibly high-level and still very strong growth there. But try and take that into contact with the growth in margins that you keep seeing in that business to levels that certainly seem a lot higher than you would anticipate for an Amazon business. Is there any capacity constraint or management that -- that's driving pricing strategy in AWS. We've heard the comments about the number of availability, zones that are being launched this year, which is obviously about a big part of driving incremental capacity in that business I'm just trying to balance those to think about how we should balance those 3 things.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me work backwards from your footprint question or comment. We have -- we just announced Korea as region and we'll be adding 5 more regions in the next -- in the future, in the near future as we mentioned. CapEx, let me start with that first. Cap
componenttext: Sure. Let me work backwards from your footprint question or comment. We have -- we just announced Korea as region and we'll be adding 5 more regions in the next -- in the future, in the near future as we mentioned. CapEx, let me start with that first. CapEx, we've seen great efficiencies in capital expenditures in, particularly in AWS, and we continue to work on better purchase efficiencies and driving utilization rates in our data centers. CapEx, as I mentioned, grew quite a bit in 2014. It grew even more to over $9 billion across all of our capital expenditures and capital leases in 2015. From the new regions, they're not in the major driver in anyway. Most of our capacity and that capital and capital leases in AWS is to service existing regions and existing customers demand growth. But there certainly expenditures, when we open up new regions, some of that is not always in the year that we opened the region. So we spent a good bit on those new regions already in 2015. As far as pricing, there's no capacity constraint, and I would -- a little bit dispute the deceleration comment on the, yes, on a percentage basis, 1,600 [ph] percent is lower than Q3, but as I said before, we're approaching a $10 billion run rate in this business on a dollar basis. We continue to grow -- we saw the greatest growth year-over-year and quarter-over-quarter. And again, we continue to invent about price. We continue to innovate on behalf of customers and we see great customer response.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: First question is if you can provide maybe some context around linearity within Q4, more as compared to your expectations. Obviously have a ramp-up into the holiday season, but was the December tail off faster than expected? Or did the ramp-up -- did it spike higher than you expected? And then just as a follow-up, maybe you can add some context about how the mobile played a role in the holiday season for Amazon.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in terms of -- this is Phil. In terms of expectations, I think we were pleased with what we saw this Q4 and if you look at what we gave for guidance, we were in the upper half of the range there for revenue. So no real callouts there, I think. What was
componenttext:
So in terms of -- this is Phil. In terms of expectations, I think we were pleased with what we saw this Q4 and if you look at what we gave for guidance, we were in the upper half of the range there for revenue. So no real callouts there, I think. What was the second part of your question?
Oh, and mobile, we said for a long time, continues to be a tailwind for the business. We're working very hard to make sure that it's very easy for customers to buy the things they want to buy and access a lot of features that they've grown accustomed to on the website. And. So we're very focused on the convenience factor and if you look at some of our new offerings like Prime, now that's available through a mobile app and there are a very convenient for customers, as Brian has mentioned, allowed them to shop even up to Christmas Eve and have their items delivered in 2 hours.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Carlos Kirjner with Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Carlos Kirjner with Bernstein.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2. I want to go back to AWS margins. You talked briefly about purchasing an asset securitization, but do these explain the 800 bps or so year-on-year margin expansion? Are you seeing anything else like is there any part of scale driving leverage ov
componenttext: I have 2. I want to go back to AWS margins. You talked briefly about purchasing an asset securitization, but do these explain the 800 bps or so year-on-year margin expansion? Are you seeing anything else like is there any part of scale driving leverage over fixed cost? Is there some benefit from revenue mix just like services like Aurora and going faster than it is due or it is all the margin expansion due to purchasing and asset utilization? So that's the first question. And the second, I have a question about your streaming content expenses or cost of revenues, to be more precise. Last year, you told us they were $1.3 billion, but you didn't give us a figure for '15. In lieu of that, can you comment on whether 4Q saw a higher than usual cost for streaming content compared to the other quarters in the year?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Carlos, this is Phil. So your question about the AWS margin, that business, as they continue to learn and as we continue to invent and get better at designing and operating the infrastructure and assets, we have been able to drive costs out of that busine
componenttext: Carlos, this is Phil. So your question about the AWS margin, that business, as they continue to learn and as we continue to invent and get better at designing and operating the infrastructure and assets, we have been able to drive costs out of that business. And so that's one of the primary drivers of the improvements that you see in margin year-over-year. There's also an FX tailwind in there as well, which I think is about $60 million this quarter, which we contributed on a year-over-year basis, which really arises because we're largely priced in dollars, but have assets with local currency costs throughout the world. As for the streaming content, we haven't given another update this year and haven't given any commentary on the profile quarter-to-quarter.

componenttext: This is Phil. So on the Dash front, we're really excited about what we're delivering there. I think as you saw the release, there's some new devices that take advantage of the underlying service that we think will be really convenient for sellers and interesting for device makers. So we're excited about what we're building there. I don't have any stats for you today. On the Twitch side, we can do to let Twitch do what Twitch does best and we don't have any updates on numbers there, but they continue to really engage customers and offer really unique experience, which is one of the reasons we were attracted to them to start with.

componenttext: I just wanted to quickly revisit the margin pendulum question and some of your comments as you mentioned that the kind of expect it to ebb and flow. Could you tell us a few expected to ebb and flow with moving higher or is ebb and flow just mean that it's kind of undetermined in 2016. And then second follow-up is the robotics, any update in terms of number of robots or how you see that expansion going forward.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, my comment on ebb and flow was more about the investment and also, including capital expenses and capital leases. So not around gross margins and merely I was pointing out that again, we've laid out all the investigators where we're seeing heavy inve
componenttext: Yes, my comment on ebb and flow was more about the investment and also, including capital expenses and capital leases. So not around gross margins and merely I was pointing out that again, we've laid out all the investigators where we're seeing heavy investment. We continue =we see a continuation of that certainly into 2016 and beyond. There are quarter-over-quarter and even year-to-year fluctuations in some accounts and some investment areas. But generally, we're pretty transparent on where we're investing our dollars. And against that backdrop, we're always looking for efficiency and the nice thing about growing the top line at such a high cliff yes, we have a lot more areas for opportunities to save money year-over-year. We always look to do that.

componenttext: And this is Phil. The question the last update we've given is more than 30,000 robots. We continue to be really pleased with the program and like what it does in the warehouse both from density storage as well as from making the jobs easier for [indiscernible] picking packages by bringing the packages actually to the associates, but no new numbers on that.

componenttext: Two questions. Was there any category mix impacts in the quarter on gross margins, that's just the quick one. And then secondly, as you look back at last year, you had some quarters where you really exceeded our guidance on the CSOI line. Maybe looking back are may be looking forward, what are the types of things that causes you to come in at the high-end versus maybe the low end when you look back or when you look forward.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. First on guidance. We keep it pretty consistent process on how we look at guidance and how we value that or how we estimate the near-term view of the business. I will point out that Q4 is obviously very large quarter, the largest revenue quarter by
componenttext: Sure. First on guidance. We keep it pretty consistent process on how we look at guidance and how we value that or how we estimate the near-term view of the business. I will point out that Q4 is obviously very large quarter, the largest revenue quarter by far of the year. There's a lot of demand that comes in in the last 6 weeks of the year as well. So very, very little visibility at the time of guidance when we do the call. So we do our best projections on a lot of fronts. We think it's a similar -- we know it's a consistent process and there are times when we underwrite and sometimes, we overrun it.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Phil. On the category mix question, obviously, category mix does play a role in gross margin. I would say though that we're much more focused on operating profit dollars and free cash flow dollars as we've probably talked about before. The gross m
componenttext: This is Phil. On the category mix question, obviously, category mix does play a role in gross margin. I would say though that we're much more focused on operating profit dollars and free cash flow dollars as we've probably talked about before. The gross margins are impacted by first party versus third-party mix as well as a to be has mix if you're looking at the total for the company. So we're much, much more focused on the dollars and no specific categories we're calling out as a driver for gross margin because again, we're much more focused on the profit dollars.

Is it the density of the market, is it the proximity of your distribution to just a color on that would be great.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we deliver really quickly a couple of ways. One is the free same day that you've seen us rollout in a number of markets here in the U.S. There is Prime Now, and we're now in more than 25 metropolitan areas for Prime Now. And delivering for free in 2 ho
componenttext: So we deliver really quickly a couple of ways. One is the free same day that you've seen us rollout in a number of markets here in the U.S. There is Prime Now, and we're now in more than 25 metropolitan areas for Prime Now. And delivering for free in 2 hours is difficult and expensive, but customers love it. We feel it missed of the natural evolution of our delivery, and we're happy to invest in that service. We like what it does for Prime members. We like the convenience factor. And so we're taking a long-term approach and doing what we normally do, which is really focused on continuing to drive greater and greater efficiency.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: So I want to ask a little more about North America operating margins because I think they expanded just under 50 bps this quarter to 4.7%. And that compares to an average of 200 basis points thereabout expansion the prior 3 [ph] quarters. So I'm just wondering if in 4Q may be higher FDA cost or something else in there that led to maybe an expansion not as great as we saw on the prior quarters. And following up on their Prime Now question, just now, I'm wondering how our delivery or 2-hour delivery has changed consumer's perception of just delivery overall.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Again, I'll point out that the demand for FBA services was very high. Nearly 50% of our third-party units again were FBA. And the demand for space and services was very large by our seller base, which was a great, great from a lot of standpoints. Bu
componenttext: Sure. Again, I'll point out that the demand for FBA services was very high. Nearly 50% of our third-party units again were FBA. And the demand for space and services was very large by our seller base, which was a great, great from a lot of standpoints. But it did exceed our expectations, but it did make our warehouses rather full and did cause us to incur some variable cost in the U.S. And also the dynamic that we work for building more of these units ourselves out of our warehouses because of the FBA growth and the retail growth.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the speed of delivery, this is Phil. All I can say is that customers love this service. It's very convenient and it gives them flexibility to get products really quickly. I don't know that there's any big trends we're ready to call out at this point, b
componenttext: On the speed of delivery, this is Phil. All I can say is that customers love this service. It's very convenient and it gives them flexibility to get products really quickly. I don't know that there's any big trends we're ready to call out at this point, but they seem to really, really like it. So we're encouraged by that. We're excited to invest in it, and we're excited what we can do for our prime members.

componenttext: Two questions, please. One is Echo perform well. Can you talk more about me about your Internet of Things ambitions and kind of how Echo plays into that strategy? And exactly, just wanted to know a little bit more about restaurant delivery. This outside of the wheelhouse and what's the impetus by doing more in terms of food delivery and what are your ambitions there?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the Echo, we like how echoes done really excited about the ecosystem and some of the new skills that are being added to Echo as well, some of the other devices. They're taking advantage of Alexa, which is kind of to bring to behind echo. So we like
componenttext: So on the Echo, we like how echoes done really excited about the ecosystem and some of the new skills that are being added to Echo as well, some of the other devices. They're taking advantage of Alexa, which is kind of to bring to behind echo. So we like our device business, general view probably saw from the press release, we had a good Q4 where we did almost doubled or doubled what we did last year. So very excited about the devices. We like to take pump more energy into Prime and really the whole ecosystem. Not sure on the Internet of Things, but it's a very exciting for devices standpoint. And the brains of Echo are in the AWS cloud. And so echo gets new capabilities as Alexa gets better and better. On the restaurant delivery, it's just another great service we can offer for our Prime members. This is tied with the Prime now offering in cities at this point. And so we have been delivery people going out and making the deliveries in the neighborhoods. And so this is one more really valuable convenient service we can offer for our Prime customers.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. First one, shipping costs were higher than we expected. I think it was 12.5% of net revenue versus 11% last year. I think just any color on the higher shipping cost and is that percentage on that revenue a new normal as we are in 2016 now a
componenttext: Two questions. First one, shipping costs were higher than we expected. I think it was 12.5% of net revenue versus 11% last year. I think just any color on the higher shipping cost and is that percentage on that revenue a new normal as we are in 2016 now and as we look out. And then the second question on Prime Now, in 25 markets globally, how should we think about the total number of markets that additional markets you can enter with the Prime Now offering in 2016.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, as you say, net shipping margin was up 70 basis points year-over-year. Again, this is all tied in with the increase in FBA growth and the demand for Prime members. We're shipping more units, more of our units. So that triples through our ship c
componenttext: Sure. Yes, as you say, net shipping margin was up 70 basis points year-over-year. Again, this is all tied in with the increase in FBA growth and the demand for Prime members. We're shipping more units, more of our units. So that triples through our ship cost per unit. And again, the calculation of ship cost as margin, as a percent of revenue, and that is impacted by the denominator effect on the FBA sales, not being booked at a net revenue.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Related to your Prime Now question, this is Phil. We're in more than 25 Metropolitan locations. If you've been watching this roll out has really happened in the last year. So it's pretty rapid rollout, and we're excited to bring it to more places. We don'
componenttext: Related to your Prime Now question, this is Phil. We're in more than 25 Metropolitan locations. If you've been watching this roll out has really happened in the last year. So it's pretty rapid rollout, and we're excited to bring it to more places. We don't have a target for you today, but we're working hard to bring you to more and more places. We're outside the U.S. now and a handful of countries in U.K. and Japan and Italy and working to expand. So this program are really excited about. We're happy to bring it to more customers.

componenttext: Thank you for joining us on the call today and for your questions. A replay will be available on our Investor Relations website at least through the end of the quarter. We appreciate your interest in Amazon.com, and we look forward to talking with you again next quarter.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for standing by. Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Amazon.com Q4 2015 Financial Results Teleconference. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks, I will be turning the call over to the Director of Invest
componenttext:
Thank you for standing by. Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Amazon.com Q4 2015 Financial Results Teleconference. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. 
For opening remarks, I will be turning the call over to the Director of Investor Relations, Phil Hardin. Please go ahead.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to our Q4 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. Joining us today is Brian Olsavsky, our CFO. We will be available for questions after our prepared remarks. The following discussion and responses to your questions reflect management's
componenttext:
Hello, and welcome to our Q4 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. Joining us today is Brian Olsavsky, our CFO. We will be available for questions after our prepared remarks. The following discussion and responses to your questions reflect management's views as of today, January 28, 2016, only and will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially. Additional information about factors that could potentially impact our financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, including our most recent Annual Report on Form 10-K. 
As you listen to today's conference call, we encourage you to have our press release in front of you, which includes our financial results as well as metrics and commentary on the quarter. 
During this call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures in our press release, slides accompanying this webcast and our filings with the SEC, each of which is posted on our IR website. You will find additional disclosures regarding these non-GAAP measures, including reconciliations of these measures with comparable GAAP measures. 
Finally, unless otherwise stated, all comparisons in this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2014. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Brian.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Phil. I'll begin with comments on our fourth quarter financial results. Trailing 12-month operating cash flow increased 74% to $11.9 billion. Trailing 12-month free cash flow increased to $7.3 billion, up from $1.9 billion. Trailing 12-month free
componenttext:
Thanks, Phil. I'll begin with comments on our fourth quarter financial results. Trailing 12-month operating cash flow increased 74% to $11.9 billion. Trailing 12-month free cash flow increased to $7.3 billion, up from $1.9 billion. Trailing 12-month free cash flow less lease principal repayments increased to $4.7 billion, up from $529 million. Trailing 12-month free cash flow less finance lease principal repayments and assets acquired under capital leases increased to $2.5 billion, up from an outflow of $2.2 billion. Trailing 12-month capital expenditures were $4.6 billion. Capital expenditures does not include the impact of property and equipment acquired under capital and finance lease obligations. These capital expenditures and capital leases reflect additional investments in support of continued business growth due to investments in technology infrastructure, the majority of which is to support AWS, and additional capacity to support our Fulfillment operations. The combination of common stock and stock-based awards outstanding was 490 million shares compared with 483 million 1 year ago. 
Worldwide revenue increased 22% to $35.7 billion or 26% excluding the $1.2 billion unfavorable impact from year-over-year changes in foreign exchange. Worldwide paid unit growth was 26%. Worldwide active customer accounts were approximately 304 million. Excluding customers who only had 3 orders in the preceding 12-month period, worldwide active customer accounts were approximately 280 million, up from approximately 254 million in the comparable prior-year period. Worldwide paid prime members increased 51% year-over-year. Worldwide seller units represented 47% of paid units. Fulfillment by Amazon or FBA units represent nearly 50% of seller units. Worldwide active Amazon Web Services customers exceeded 1 million. 
Now I'll discuss operating expenses excluding stock-based compensation. Cost of sales was $24.3 billion or 68.1% of revenue compared with 70.5%. Fulfillment, marketing, technology and content and G&A combined was $9.7 billion or 27.1% of sales, up approximately 100 basis points year-over-year. Fulfillment was $4.4 billion or 12.3% of revenue compared with 11.3%. Tech and content was $3.2 billion or 9% of revenue compared with 8.2%. Marketing was $1.7 billion or 4.8% of revenue compared with 5.1%. 
Now I'll talk about our segment results. As a reminder, in the first quarter, we changed our reportable segments to report North America, international and Amazon Web Services. Consistent with prior periods, we do not allocate to our segments our stock-based compensation or the other operating expense line item. In the North America segment, revenue grew 24% to $21.5 billion. Media revenue grew 11% to $3.9 billion or 12% excluding foreign exchange. EGM revenue grew 28% to $17.3 billion. North America segment operating income was $1 billion, a 4.7% operating margin, compared with $733 million in the prior year period. North America segment operating income includes $6 million of favorable impact from foreign exchange. 
In the international segment, revenue grew 12% to $11.8 billion. Excluding the $1.1 billion year-over-year unfavorable foreign exchange impact, revenue growth was 22%. Media revenue decreased 3% to $3.3 billion or increased 5% excluding foreign exchange. EGM revenue grew 19% to $8.5 billion or 31% excluding foreign exchange. International segment operating income was $60 million compared with $65 million in the prior year. International segment operating income includes $47 million of unfavorable impact from foreign exchange. 
In the Amazon Web Services segment, revenue grew 69% to $2.4 billion. Amazon Web Services segment operating income was $687 million, a 28.5% operating margin, compared with $240 million in the prior year period. AWS segment operating income includes $60 million of favorable impact from foreign exchange. Consolidated segment operating income was $1.8 billion or 4.9% of revenue, up approximately 140 basis points year-over-year. CSOI includes $20 million of favorable impact from foreign exchange. Unlike CSOI, our GAAP operating income includes stock-based compensation expense and other operating expense. GAAP operating income grew 88% to $1.1 billion. Our income tax expense was $453 million. GAAP net income was $482 million or $1 per diluted share compared with a net income of $214 million and $0.45 per diluted share. 
Now I'll discuss the full year results. Revenue increased 20% to $107 billion or 26% excluding year-over-year changes in foreign exchange. North America revenue grew 25% to $63.7 billion or 26%, excluding year-over-year changes in foreign exchange. International revenue grew 6% to $35.4 billion or 21% excluding year-over-year changes in foreign exchange. Excluding year-over-year changes in foreign exchange, Germany revenue grew 18%; Japan revenue grew 19%; and U.K. revenue grew 16%. AWS revenue grew 70% to $7.9 billion. Consolidated segment operating income was $4.5 billion or 4.2% of revenue, up approximately 220 basis points year-over-year. CSOI includes $16 million of favorable impact from foreign exchange. GAAP operating income was $2.2 billion compared with $178 million in the prior year. 
Turning to the balance sheet. Cash and marketable securities increased $2.4 billion year-over-year to $19.8 billion. Inventory increased 23% to $10.2 billion, and inventory turns were 8.5, down from 8.6 turns a year ago as we expanded selection, improved in-stock levels and introduced new product categories. Accounts payable increased 24% to $20.4 billion and accounts payable days increased to 77 from 73 in the prior year. 
I'll conclude my portion of today's call with guidance. Incorporated into our guidance are the order trends that we've seen to date and what we believe today to be appropriately conservative assumptions. Our results are inherently unpredictable and may be materially affected by many factors, including a high level of uncertainty surrounding exchange rate fluctuations as well as the global economy and customer spending. It's not possible to accurately predict demand and, therefore, our actual results could differ materially from our guidance. As we described in more detail on our public filings, issues such as settling intercompany balances and foreign currencies among our subsidiaries, unfavorable resolution of legal matters and changes to our effective tax rate can all have a material effect on guidance. Our guidance further assumes that we don't conclude any additional business acquisitions, investments, restructurings or legal settlements recording further revisions to stock-based compensation estimates and that foreign exchange rates remain approximately where they've been recently. 
For Q1 2016, we expect net sales of between $26.5 billion and $29 billion or growth of between 17% and 28%. This guidance anticipates approximately 130 basis points of unfavorable impact from foreign exchange rates. GAAP operating income to be between $100 million and $700 million compared with $255 million in first quarter 2015. This includes approximately $600 million for stock-based compensation and other operating expenses net. We anticipate consolidated segment operating income, which excludes stock-based compensation and other operating expense net to be between $700 million and $1.3 billion compared with $706 million in the first quarter of 2015. 
We are grateful to our customers and remain heads-down focused on driving a better customer experience. We believe putting customers first is the only reliable way to create lasting value for shareholders. 
Thanks. And with that, Phil, let's move on to questions.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Brian. Let's move on to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, will you please remind our listeners how to initiate a question?
componenttext: Great. Thanks, Brian. Let's move on to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, will you please remind our listeners how to initiate a question?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from analyst Stephen Ju with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from analyst Stephen Ju with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Brian, I think in the past you've given some indication as to what usage growth may be at AWS. I was wondering if you have an update for that in the fourth quarter. And secondarily, is there any way to characterize what the pricing environment is right
componenttext: So Brian, I think in the past you've given some indication as to what usage growth may be at AWS. I was wondering if you have an update for that in the fourth quarter. And secondarily, is there any way to characterize what the pricing environment is right now for AWS as well?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't have a usage growth number for you. I will say we're -- it's been very strong and the AWS revenue is on a -- just short of a $10 billion run rate at the end of Q4. First, pricing as concerned, we had a price reduction in January for our EC2 se
componenttext: No, I don't have a usage growth number for you. I will say we're -- it's been very strong and the AWS revenue is on a -- just short of a $10 billion run rate at the end of Q4. First, pricing as concerned, we had a price reduction in January for our EC2 services. It was our 51st price reduction since we launched AWS years ago. And generally, what we find is that price is important, but so is speed and agility for customers and the ability to deliver services and features that are beneficial to them. I will point out that we added 722 new features and services in 2015, and that was up 40% year-over-year. So we feel we have a lead in the space, and we don't take it for granted and we want to serve customers better each year.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from analyst Jason Helfstein with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question is from analyst Jason Helfstein with Oppenheimer.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about the dynamics in the fourth quarter, e-commerce, particularly in the U.S.? Did we see more aggressive promotional activity? And maybe talk about how you tried to work that to continue to drive the Prime number of numbers goi
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about the dynamics in the fourth quarter, e-commerce, particularly in the U.S.? Did we see more aggressive promotional activity? And maybe talk about how you tried to work that to continue to drive the Prime number of numbers going forward?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, what I can say is our approach to pricing has not changed, and [indiscernible] we did everything we could to have the best prices available for customers and in stock in time for the holiday. Another dynamic of Q4 was that it was a huge FBA qu
componenttext: Sure. Well, what I can say is our approach to pricing has not changed, and [indiscernible] we did everything we could to have the best prices available for customers and in stock in time for the holiday. Another dynamic of Q4 was that it was a huge FBA quarter. Nearly 50% of our third-party units were FBA and our third-party units were also up to 47% of our paid units, so up 400 basis points year-over-year. So a really strong quarter for our FBA sellers using our FBA services. It did put a lot of demands on our warehouses, and we were full. It was a very busy quarter, and it did increase some of our variable cost as a result, primarily in the U.S. But a very strong quarter for FBA. It exceeded even our expectations.

componenttext: Perhaps how you were able to integrate that into holiday promotions?

componenttext: Nothing specific. I will say one interesting enhancement this year was our Prime Now service, which allowed people to order in selected markets up til 11:59 on New Year's -- excuse me, Christmas eve. So that was a valuable service to many late shoppers, last-minute shoppers.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Aram Rubinson with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Aram Rubinson with Wolfe Research.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions, both on the logistics side. Seems pretty clear that you guys are trafficking in some old world assets like truck trailers and ship lanes and airfields. Can you help give us a sense as to maybe what we're trying to accomplish with that, if i
componenttext: Two questions, both on the logistics side. Seems pretty clear that you guys are trafficking in some old world assets like truck trailers and ship lanes and airfields. Can you help give us a sense as to maybe what we're trying to accomplish with that, if it's defensive to protect your service to your existing customers or if you're looking to maybe start new businesses with those assets?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll answer your question. I would say that what we found is, in order to properly serve our customers at peak, we've needed to add more of our own logistics to supplement our existing partners. That's not meant to replace them. And those carriers a
componenttext: Sure, I'll answer your question. I would say that what we found is, in order to properly serve our customers at peak, we've needed to add more of our own logistics to supplement our existing partners. That's not meant to replace them. And those carriers are just no longer able to handle all of our capacity that we need at peak. They've been and continue to be great partners, and we look forward to working with them in the future. It's just we've had to add some resources on our own. You mentioned trucks. The Amazon trucks, we did invest in those this past year. We use those primarily for movement between our warehouses and our sort centers.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2. The first one is just on gross margins. I think they were down by 200 basis points sequentially. It's the biggest fall in the fourth quarter in quite some time. Anything you caught there? Is it devices or more sortation centers? Is there anythin
componenttext: I have 2. The first one is just on gross margins. I think they were down by 200 basis points sequentially. It's the biggest fall in the fourth quarter in quite some time. Anything you caught there? Is it devices or more sortation centers? Is there anything pressuring gross margins that we should think about in the fourth quarter? And then on the Fulfillment line, you mentioned FBA being a big driver of the growth in the Fulfillment cost. Anything else you would call out leading to incremental Fulfillment cost, maybe India or something else?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. And again, keep in mind that the fulfillment as a percent of revenue is impacted by the calculation of FBA revenue being a net number as opposed to a full revenue number. But our Fulfillment cost per unit actually decrease year-over-year. It's just we
componenttext: No. And again, keep in mind that the fulfillment as a percent of revenue is impacted by the calculation of FBA revenue being a net number as opposed to a full revenue number. But our Fulfillment cost per unit actually decrease year-over-year. It's just we are now shipping more and more of our -- of the demand out of our warehouses because of the strength in retail and FBA. On gross margin, I would -- first, I'll caution you and say we would encourage you to look at free cash flow, which was -- grew at a minimum $4 billion on each of the metrics that we point out and our profit, which was up 80% year-over-year. If you look sequentially, also keep in mind that in Q3, when it was up 500 basis points year-over-year, that was lapping the write-down of our Amazon phone inventory the prior year. So there's a little bit of noise in the Q3 number. But generally, again, we're happy with the ability to service customers, the reaction of customers in Q4 and the bottom line results that we had.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Colin Sebastian with Baird Equity Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Colin Sebastian with Baird Equity Research.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: One follow-up and then another question. On the logistics and transportation side, I was curious if that's today just to supplement some of the other carriers, but more broadly or longer term, is there an ambition from the services side to perhaps provide
componenttext: One follow-up and then another question. On the logistics and transportation side, I was curious if that's today just to supplement some of the other carriers, but more broadly or longer term, is there an ambition from the services side to perhaps provide capacity to other companies. And then, on the AWS margins, was just wondering if we should expect more leverage there going forward and whether Q1 -- whether that should demonstrate some seasonality versus what we've seen in terms of sequential growth in prior years.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me work backwards. Don't give guidance by segments so I cannot really comment on AWS specifically in Q1. The -- and the operational improvements -- excuse me, the gross margin -- operating margin year-over-year that we've seen in the AWS busines
componenttext: Sure. Let me work backwards. Don't give guidance by segments so I cannot really comment on AWS specifically in Q1. The -- and the operational improvements -- excuse me, the gross margin -- operating margin year-over-year that we've seen in the AWS business has been heavily driven by operating efficiencies, both purchase reductions and purchase prices and also efficiency in driving greater utilization of the assets that we have. So I'm very happy with that. Keep in mind that we did have a -- although the year-over-year increase in capital expenditures and capital leases was not as great as we saw in 2013 to 2014, we did spend over $9 billion on those -- on capital expenditures and capital lease obligations, up from -- prior year was -- excuse me...
