headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Mark May of Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Mark May of Citi.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Lots, lots here but international retail revenue, the international regional segment really stood out. Revenue accelerated. It seemed like a bit of a milestone also that the CSOI turned positive in a non-Q4 quarter. Can you shed any more light in what the
componenttext: Lots, lots here but international retail revenue, the international regional segment really stood out. Revenue accelerated. It seemed like a bit of a milestone also that the CSOI turned positive in a non-Q4 quarter. Can you shed any more light in what the key driver there was and how sustainable it is? And AWS just mathematically, the comps get tougher starting in Q2, just given what happened in 2014. Is that something that we should be taking into account in terms of thinking about how the rest of the year may progress?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Your first question on international, yes, all 3 segments had very strong growth in the quarter. International's 26% for FX-neutral growth rate was actually the strongest we've seen in 3.5 years. I would attribute it to the Prime Flywheel. As may ha
componenttext: Sure. Your first question on international, yes, all 3 segments had very strong growth in the quarter. International's 26% for FX-neutral growth rate was actually the strongest we've seen in 3.5 years. I would attribute it to the Prime Flywheel. As may have mentioned in the past, Europe and large countries in Europe and Japan are a few years behind the U.S. on a lot of the key Prime metrics, but we also said last year that Prime subscriptions were up 51% year-over-year in 2015, 47% of that was -- 47% in the U.S. and higher rate than that internationally. So certainly a lot going on in the international, a lot that's really good adding Prime subscribers at a high clip, continue to add selection at FBA sellers. So you'll see device,  you see devices, you see video content. So it's the whole array of Prime offering, Prime Now same-day everything is in Europe. It's maybe getting there a little slower than starting point in the U.S. but we see it really showing up in customer engagement and customer purchases. On the AWS side, I think the 2016 to 2015 comparison probably stands on its own and 2014 false by the wayside. So I would encourage you to look at recent trend. We don't forecast obviously by segment.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Douglas Anmuth, JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Douglas Anmuth, JPMorgan.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to ask you about unit growth overall, and if we look back over the last 3 quarters, you've accelerated it now to materially higher level than what we saw in '14 and the first half of '15. And I realize in 3Q last year, you had Prime Day.
componenttext: So I just wanted to ask you about unit growth overall, and if we look back over the last 3 quarters, you've accelerated it now to materially higher level than what we saw in '14 and the first half of '15. And I realize in 3Q last year, you had Prime Day. But was just hoping you could comment on kind of the overall acceleration we've seen here in key drivers behind that. And if there's something different perhaps than what he talked about on international. And then just also on AWS. Can you just talk about the underlying drivers here of margins and thinking about that a little bit going forward, kind of primary sources of leverage? And as you open up 6 new regions in coming months, should we expect this to be kind of constant build-out or something that's kind of more lumpy over time and more in waves?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Phil Hardin, I'll take the units question. So really the units are driven by very similar trends to what Brian described. I think when we look at the bridges for revenue and obviously, units are a key driver of revenue, things like Prime are a key
componenttext: This is Phil Hardin, I'll take the units question. So really the units are driven by very similar trends to what Brian described. I think when we look at the bridges for revenue and obviously, units are a key driver of revenue, things like Prime are a key in that bridge. I would also call out selection growth. That's been a big area of focus for us. And one important way we drive selection is through FBA. And so we continue to be very pleased with the progress we're making in FBA. What that means for our Prime customers is there's more for them to choose from. Obviously, that gives them more they can purchase, it makes Prime more valuable. For sellers, it means they sell more. And so I would say that FBA is helping drive some of the selection growth we're seeing here. So selection growth and Prime though are 2 very key drivers of our growth. On the second part, Brian?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: One other comment I didn't say earlier, I do want to point out that because of the leap year, there's an extra day in Q1. Every company would have seen this obviously, but we'd estimate it was worth about 150 basis points to our growth rate in revenue. Th
componenttext: One other comment I didn't say earlier, I do want to point out that because of the leap year, there's an extra day in Q1. Every company would have seen this obviously, but we'd estimate it was worth about 150 basis points to our growth rate in revenue. That would be consistent North America and international. The other comment was -- or question was on AWS and a bit about margins and margin outlook. We're very pleased with the quarter. We came in at 23.5% operating margin on a -- the new basis, including stock-based compensation and other. We're very pleased [indiscernible] back the 54% growth in AWS, which is now a $10 billion business. But on the margin side, I would caution you that we're pleased, but it is very early to start drawing too many conclusions on the long-term margins in this business. They'll be bumpy over time. At any point in time, they're going to reflect the balance of investing, including global expansion talked about, price reductions we may offer and also driving cost efficiency, which for us is a very important driver in this business but also the North American and international segments.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking at the active customer account number, it looks like growth slowed pretty significantly, about 10 percentage points from. Just curious if you can give us a sense of anything that might be throwing that number off, assuming we're reading it the rig
componenttext: Looking at the active customer account number, it looks like growth slowed pretty significantly, about 10 percentage points from. Just curious if you can give us a sense of anything that might be throwing that number off, assuming we're reading it the right way. And then as you roll out on AWS, as you roll out the 6 new availability zones over the course of this year, is there a way to quantify what kind of an impact that's going to have on the capacity at AWS?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll take the first part of your question about active customers. So as we look at our metrics and what information we provide each year, we often make some changes. So this quarter, we only gave the active customers with a pay purchase in the trailing
componenttext: So I'll take the first part of your question about active customers. So as we look at our metrics and what information we provide each year, we often make some changes. So this quarter, we only gave the active customers with a pay purchase in the trailing 12 months. So that number was more than 285 million. I think that's pretty similar to the trend that we've seen in that metric. Now in the past, sometimes, we've also given a total active customers count. And so that number for this quarter was 310 -- over 310 million. So that may be where you're making the statement about the slowdown in growth. The trajectory was very similar from prior quarters for both these numbers, but we opted just to give the other one, but you now have the number for the total number of customers [indiscernible] And on your AWS footprint question, so we ended the quarter with 33 available -- availability zones and 12 geographic regions. And we have 5 -- 11 more availability zones opening in the next year. The impact on capital, yes, there will be additional capital investment as we build out the zones. Some of these already taking place. But I will also say that, by and large, the largest increases in capital leases is growth of incremental usage of customers we have now and regions we have now. And you should expect to see us continue to invest and support this business for are very, very -- [indiscernible] position we intend to maintain it, and we're very excited about where we are.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: 2, please. The first one is on Prime. You've had 2 straight years of around 50% Prime subscriber growth. Just curious about how you think about keys to driving Prime sub growth going forward and kind of the thought process behind the reported monthly Prim
componenttext: 2, please. The first one is on Prime. You've had 2 straight years of around 50% Prime subscriber growth. Just curious about how you think about keys to driving Prime sub growth going forward and kind of the thought process behind the reported monthly Prime subscription. And the second one on logistics investments. There's been a lot about kind of truck investments, logistics investments. Any comment at all about learnings and what you're seeing from some of the investments in your truck fleet and your own delivery network?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me start with the Prime. Yes, we have had very strong growth in last 2 years and earlier obviously on Prime growth numbers. I would say it's a combination of a lot of separate investments that we're making. So if you look at the success of our de
componenttext: Yes, let me start with the Prime. Yes, we have had very strong growth in last 2 years and earlier obviously on Prime growth numbers. I would say it's a combination of a lot of separate investments that we're making. So if you look at the success of our devices, we are seeing -- tablets were sold twice the volume in Q1 year-over-year. Fire TV Stick, you may have read in our press release that it has greater than 100,000 customer reviews, the most reviewed product ever. 62,000 or over 62,000 of those reviews are 5-star reviews. We've not only have the Echo, but we have the Echo Dot and Tab so we're branching off that product line and having trouble keeping those in stock. And of course, we launched the new Kindle Oasis e-reader. So that is important part of the story as is the digital content. You may have seen the recent announcements that we're working on a great amount of new content for Prime members. We love the -- customers love the content and we like the results. We see particularly around Prime free trial conversion and renewal rates for subscribers who use -- take advantage of Prime. So beyond the award that the content is winning and success we're having with Amazon, particularly Amazon originals, we feel that program's working. We're going to significantly increase our spend in that area. Some of that is in Q2. You'll see that more in the next few quarters. But we think that's working and look forward to bringing a lot of new content to our Prime subscriber base, both to our normal Prime subscription and also the monthly plan that you alluded to.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Phil Hardin, I'll jump in the second part of your question. So for the trucks, it really is trailers. The typical use case is running a lag between a fulfillment center and a source center. So we're running enough volume there that we're using tru
componenttext: This is Phil Hardin, I'll jump in the second part of your question. So for the trucks, it really is trailers. The typical use case is running a lag between a fulfillment center and a source center. So we're running enough volume there that we're using trucks already. We thought it made sense to go ahead and buy some trailers actually feel contracting the truck part. And it gives us flexibility. We think the economics makes sense over time. Similarly, we've announced an agreement to lease some airplanes with Air Transport Services Group, an agreement to lease up to 20 Boeing 767s there and similar use case, its products that are already boxed. And we think again this is activities we've been doing already, which grow at a very rapid rate. This gives us extra capacity we think it could be able to deliver to customers, and we think it makes sense over the long term.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Mark Mahaney of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question comes from Mark Mahaney of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions related to Prime overseas. Could you talk about the status of Prime in international markets? How rolled out it is in most of your major markets? And then you talked about Prime flywheels, and you did last year, but it seems like those Flywh
componenttext: Two questions related to Prime overseas. Could you talk about the status of Prime in international markets? How rolled out it is in most of your major markets? And then you talked about Prime flywheels, and you did last year, but it seems like those Flywheels spun faster than you expected in the fourth quarter of last year that caused some kind of near-term expense issues for you. Can you talk about how you're thinking about planning against that as of their Prime flywheels getting broader for you? How do you try to get ahead of that into the peak season later this year?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Brian. Let me start with the second question first. It wasn't necessarily the Prime flywheel that was the issue. It was more the FBA demand that we had from FBA sellers for space in our warehouses. We were very full. It was a high-class problem to
componenttext: This is Brian. Let me start with the second question first. It wasn't necessarily the Prime flywheel that was the issue. It was more the FBA demand that we had from FBA sellers for space in our warehouses. We were very full. It was a high-class problem to have. But as I mentioned, last quarter, it did result in higher fulfillment costs in the fourth quarter as a result. I think you'll see some of that dissipating now Q1 so it's a Q4 issue. We learn from every Q4. This one was no exception. We are already making plans for a smoother Q4 next year. We will continue to add fulfillment capacity. We'll work with FBA sellers on inventory stocking and timing. And we think that there's things that we can do better as we do every year come out of the fourth quarter with what the earnings.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Phil. On the Prime question, we launched Prime in the U.S. in 2005, followed that in 2007 with U.K., Germany, Japan and then other countries after. We have Prime in all of the countries where we have marketplaces, with the exception of Mexico, Chi
componenttext: This is Phil. On the Prime question, we launched Prime in the U.S. in 2005, followed that in 2007 with U.K., Germany, Japan and then other countries after. We have Prime in all of the countries where we have marketplaces, with the exception of Mexico, China and India. And Prime is really in varying stages in those countries. We have some kind of expedited shipping offer in all of them. Here in the U.S., we've been talking quite a bit about Prime now. But also in Italy and Japan and U.K. at this point and not others. Also varying levels of digital benefits as well. So generally, the international countries are not as far along with selection for the digital offers. We've got Prime Video in the U.K., in Germany, in Japan. Music is not fully rolled out yet altogether. So that's where we are with Prime.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our  next question comes from Carlos Kirjner with Bernstein.
componenttext: Our  next question comes from Carlos Kirjner with Bernstein.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2. I think the first time since 1Q '11 that we see [indiscernible] as a percentage of revenue declining or flat. Is this just a sign of your inability to increase investment in line with revenue growth? Or is there something else going on and if ye
componenttext: I have 2. I think the first time since 1Q '11 that we see [indiscernible] as a percentage of revenue declining or flat. Is this just a sign of your inability to increase investment in line with revenue growth? Or is there something else going on and if yes, what? And secondly, Brian, you said that the growth of Prime has been driven by investments you've made and are making. And you gave the examples of devices you guys are selling. I think it's a mathematical certainty that Prime subscribers will decelerate in North America at some point from 50% growth. As penetration increases and growth slows, we will see a deceleration in the investment levels. And in other words, how do you think about the effect of the deceleration in Prime on the North America margin structure in the future?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me start with that second one. So we think there's a lot of room to grow in not only our international countries but also in the U.S. So we plan on continuing to build the benefit of the Prime program from music to video to 2-day shipping to sam
componenttext: Sure. Let me start with that second one. So we think there's a lot of room to grow in not only our international countries but also in the U.S. So we plan on continuing to build the benefit of the Prime program from music to video to 2-day shipping to same-day shipping to Prime Now. So I don't see that dissipating. And again, it remains the best deal in retail so hopefully, everyone signs up for that. On the Tech and Content question, I don't have a lot to call out in the quarter. I would say there's no let-up in the pace of invention here, particularly on the AWS side. We had -- the number of new features and services to you each quarter. We had 214 in Q1, up from 170 this first quarter of last year. So over 26% growth in this quarter alone coming off a year where I believe the number's 722 significant new features and services delivered for AWS customers last year.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Pitz of Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Pitz of Jefferies.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any comments on your business in India? How's that market ramping up? And maybe on the competitive front there, any sense of where the local incumbents may actually have some advantage in the region?
componenttext: Any comments on your business in India? How's that market ramping up? And maybe on the competitive front there, any sense of where the local incumbents may actually have some advantage in the region?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Thanks. Actually, I just returned from India where I spent a week with our teams in Bangalore and Hyderabad. We're breaking ground on our new 10-acre campus there so we are solidifying and increasing our investment in India on all fronts. I had
componenttext: Yes, sure. Thanks. Actually, I just returned from India where I spent a week with our teams in Bangalore and Hyderabad. We're breaking ground on our new 10-acre campus there so we are solidifying and increasing our investment in India on all fronts. I had a chance to see first-hand the global invention going on with both customers and sellers making deliveries to customers, seeing space program we have with merchants. It's a very exciting time in India. And again, the invention is off the charts. We're inventing things in India that do not exist in other parts of the country -- or excuse me, parts of the world. And the team there is one of our best. You can see in some of the external commentary as well, the second year in a row customer selected Amazon India as Amazon's most trusted online shopping brand. During the quarter, we rolled out a feature called which is a studio on wheels that we go to the sellers to help them sign up. We let them do registration, imaging, catalog, uploads and basic seller training. So we're taking it to the sellers, taking the business to the sellers. We've already reached sellers in 25 cities, and we're really helping them expand their business not only within their home region throughout the whole country.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Justin Post of Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Justin Post of Merrill Lynch.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question's on international margins. They're quite a bit below where they were many years ago and trailing the U.S. Maybe talk about the dynamics there and what's it going to take a kind of catch up over time?
componenttext: My question's on international margins. They're quite a bit below where they were many years ago and trailing the U.S. Maybe talk about the dynamics there and what's it going to take a kind of catch up over time?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So on the op margin side, although there was improvement year-over-year, you're right there's still, on an FX-neutral basis, negative. We have, as I said earlier, selection expansion, infrastructure investments to fulfillment network and AWS, excuse
componenttext: Sure. So on the op margin side, although there was improvement year-over-year, you're right there's still, on an FX-neutral basis, negative. We have, as I said earlier, selection expansion, infrastructure investments to fulfillment network and AWS, excuse me, that's not the international segment. Fulfillment network and digital content. So we continue to build the underpinnings of the Prime program in international countries. You also have to keep in mind that we're making large investments in India. We're very excited about what we see and we will continue to invest heavily in India.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ross Sandler with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ross Sandler with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had 2 questions on AWS. First, last fall at reinvent, you guys disclosed that data management revenue was at a $1 billion run rate. So can you provide an update on that figure and maybe just talk about how much of AWS revenue today is outside of th
componenttext: I just had 2 questions on AWS. First, last fall at reinvent, you guys disclosed that data management revenue was at a $1 billion run rate. So can you provide an update on that figure and maybe just talk about how much of AWS revenue today is outside of the storage and compute layers? And then the second question is on the AWS margin. So I think everybody is trying to learn more about the structural long-term margin, and it was down a tad quarter-on-quarter. So was that solely from FX impact or was there some seasonality of expenses? Any color on what's driving the AWS margin and how we should think about that over the longer term?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take your second question first. So again, we had margin expansion year-over-year that was quite significant from 12.4% to 23.5%. But again, it's very early in this business. We're very pleased with the results we're seeing on the top and bottom line
componenttext: I'll take your second question first. So again, we had margin expansion year-over-year that was quite significant from 12.4% to 23.5%. But again, it's very early in this business. We're very pleased with the results we're seeing on the top and bottom line, but margins are going to be bumpy and affected by levels of investing, price reductions and also cost efficiencies that we're driving. So quarter to quarter, it will vary. We are concerned at this point about capital efficiency, returning price to customers periodically with price reduction and adding feature sets for them to make business more valuable.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Phil. For your other part of your question, we're not providing an update on the $1 billion stat. What I would say is that the AWS team has strong revenue growth across their suite of products. The fastest-growing product in their history is actua
componenttext: This is Phil. For your other part of your question, we're not providing an update on the $1 billion stat. What I would say is that the AWS team has strong revenue growth across their suite of products. The fastest-growing product in their history is actually Aurora, the new database. So we're very excited about what we're seeing in that space but we're not breaking out the revenue [indiscernible].

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Eric Sheridan of UBS Investment Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Eric Sheridan of UBS Investment Research.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking at the gross margin, impressive performance in Q1. There were a few headwinds that looked like in gross margin in Q4. Wanted to understand how we should think about the puts and takes in gross margin. It's evolved to be a much higher number over t
componenttext: Looking at the gross margin, impressive performance in Q1. There were a few headwinds that looked like in gross margin in Q4. Wanted to understand how we should think about the puts and takes in gross margin. It's evolved to be a much higher number over the last couple of years. What's some of the puts and takes are going forward especially with respect to content cost?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I don't have a forecast for you on content cost in isolation or really forward looks on besides of the guidance I've given you. But yes, the hits in the gross margin are content cost do show up there. I think the bigger issues that you should loo
componenttext: Sure. So I don't have a forecast for you on content cost in isolation or really forward looks on besides of the guidance I've given you. But yes, the hits in the gross margin are content cost do show up there. I think the bigger issues that you should look at in gross margin and again starting with the comment that we've expanded by 300 basis points year-over-year, that is really driven by, first of all, the AWS growth and again $10 billion -- excuse me, $10 billion business growing 64% is very -- we're very pleased with that and that gross margin as well. The other bigger element of that is the third-party contribution. Third-party units are now up to 48% of paid units. That's up 400 basis points year-over-year. So that continues to be a factor in gross margin. Again, we book that on a net basis. The third-party revenue, it's a positive factor in gross margin that could be a negative factor in fulfillment cost and some of the other metrics.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And also just to jump in gross margin is not the primary metric we use to measure the business much more focused on free cash flow dollars and operating profit dollars. So there are a whole lot of moving parts in gross margin and Brian mentioned a lot of
componenttext: And also just to jump in gross margin is not the primary metric we use to measure the business much more focused on free cash flow dollars and operating profit dollars. So there are a whole lot of moving parts in gross margin and Brian mentioned a lot of them but it's not a primary metric for us.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Aaron Kessler of Raymond James.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. First, if you can update on some of your new advertising initiatives in terms of how the sponsored links are performing. Additionally, if you could give us an update on Prime announcement you rolled out a number of [indiscernible] h
componenttext: A couple of questions. First, if you can update on some of your new advertising initiatives in terms of how the sponsored links are performing. Additionally, if you could give us an update on Prime announcement you rolled out a number of [indiscernible] how that is evolving and traction with Prime Now.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we're very excited about the advertising business, and we think it's still very early days for this opportunity. So it's an offering we've been working on. We're trying to take a very customer-centric approach. You probably noticed some changes in the
componenttext: So we're very excited about the advertising business, and we think it's still very early days for this opportunity. So it's an offering we've been working on. We're trying to take a very customer-centric approach. You probably noticed some changes in the treatment on the website. And we did move away from text ads and product ads in favor of some of the other newer products. And we're really excited about the opportunity there is for third-party sellers and for other vendors on the site. But we're not breaking out numbers today.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on Prime Now, we're now in 30 metro areas. Really from a standing start 16 months ago when we opened our first Prime Now location and now worldwide business in the U.S., U.K., Italy and Japan. So the 5 cities we added in the first quarter were Ra
componenttext: And then on Prime Now, we're now in 30 metro areas. Really from a standing start 16 months ago when we opened our first Prime Now location and now worldwide business in the U.S., U.K., Italy and Japan. So the 5 cities we added in the first quarter were Raleigh, North Carolina, Cincinnati, Tampa, Liverpool, England and Osaka, Japan. So how we feel about that business, again, it offers tens of thousands of daily essential products. We think it's service the customers certainly is hard for people -- hard for companies to do. We think the natural evolution of our operations network and our scale gives us a chance to do this. And we are happy to invest in it as a service for our customers. We're taking a long-term approach on this one though.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Stephen Ju of Credit Suisse.

componenttext: So your capital lease-driven property and equipment acquisition is down again year-over-year. And I think historically on the commerce side you guys have [indiscernible] as opposed to reader. AWS, you have readers for the most part [indiscernible] now given your leadership position, do you think you'll continue to be price leaders or do you think [indiscernible]?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me start with your CapEx question. So we like to look at both capital expenditures and capital leases because they're both essentially levels investment. Those totaled $9.5 billion in the trailing 12 months, and it was up 7% from the 12-month period e
componenttext: Let me start with your CapEx question. So we like to look at both capital expenditures and capital leases because they're both essentially levels investment. Those totaled $9.5 billion in the trailing 12 months, and it was up 7% from the 12-month period ending this quarter last year. I will point out the prior year was $6.1 billion. So we have stepped up investment, although we did not go up as much as year-over-year this quarter. But we are still spending almost $10 billion on what essentially is fulfillment capacity in support of really strong growth and unit growth in FBA and global expansion and then also on AWS additional capacity for existing customers as they grow their business and also in new regions. We've been working continue to work very hard on capital productivity. It's very important to us. And I attribute a good piece of the ability to keep that at a modest growth rate year-over-year to our capital efficiency and better purchasing across all capital and capital lease quite frankly. But again, we are spending almost $10 billion so...

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Phil. Just to jump on the uses we continue to see really strong usage growth. We're not in the business of raising prices. We lower prices for AWS. So there can be mix for products but, by and large, if you see our revenue growth, we're also lower
componenttext: This is Phil. Just to jump on the uses we continue to see really strong usage growth. We're not in the business of raising prices. We lower prices for AWS. So there can be mix for products but, by and large, if you see our revenue growth, we're also lowering prices, which means that my math, we're typically going to be growing usage at very strong rates, so I just wanted to jump on that.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: So the North American EGM segment outperformed our expectations of growth accelerating on a year-over-year basis. So given you don't break out GMV by vertical within the EGM segment, and just given the strong growth massive scale, can you cite any key verticals that were particularly strong? And second question is just an update on fresh obviously been much slower than Prime Now. How should we think about the fresh rollout and impact over the long term?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Phil. I'll take the EGM question first. So just to put numbers on that, the year-over-year in the U.S. or in North America was 32% growth, which was up from 28% in Q4. And there's not any single categories we're calling out there. To grow on a bas
componenttext: This is Phil. I'll take the EGM question first. So just to put numbers on that, the year-over-year in the U.S. or in North America was 32% growth, which was up from 28% in Q4. And there's not any single categories we're calling out there. To grow on a base that big that kind of rate, you really need pretty strong performance across the board. So a lot of categories are selling a lot, and it's a lot of drivers we talked about. As Brian mentioned on the revenue growth side. Prime, selection growth, and we also benefited from the extra day in the quarter due to the leap year but strong performance for many other categories.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And our AmazonFresh, we continue to have a strong Fresh business in a number of cities in the U.S. We know customers love it. We're making good progress on the economics, and you also know that we have other ways for people consumable products. We ha
componenttext: Yes. And our AmazonFresh, we continue to have a strong Fresh business in a number of cities in the U.S. We know customers love it. We're making good progress on the economics, and you also know that we have other ways for people consumable products. We have Prime Pantry, we have Prime Now. So we're playing with a different -- a lot of different models to see what resonates with consumers and it'll guide our investment decision going forward.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ben Schachter of Macquarie Equities Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ben Schachter of Macquarie Equities Research.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple on Prime and one on China. First, a point of clarification. The answer to a previous question by saying that you will significantly increase investment in Prime, was that in reference specifically to video? Or should we expect new types of offeri
componenttext: A couple on Prime and one on China. First, a point of clarification. The answer to a previous question by saying that you will significantly increase investment in Prime, was that in reference specifically to video? Or should we expect new types of offerings beyond video and music? And then secondly on Prime. Membership is likely hitting some saturation levels for certain demographics in the U.S. Do you intend to focus on more lower income households for growth there? And then finally, quickly on China. Anything notable to call out there that's been different over the recent past driving results for the free trade zone, et cetera?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first question on content. Yes, my comment on Prime benefits was essentially one about video content and our investment there. I'm not saying other investments may not go up as well but that is the one that we are focusing on and that I call
componenttext: I'll take the first question on content. Yes, my comment on Prime benefits was essentially one about video content and our investment there. I'm not saying other investments may not go up as well but that is the one that we are focusing on and that I called out. On the comment about Prime, I guess what I would call availability or saturation, yes, I think that's one of the thoughts behind our monthly plan. We want to create flexibility for consumers to try Prime in a low cost way if that's how they choose. We've always had our free trial program but it is a hurdle for many people or there's hesitancy to put up a full year's payment for Europe Prime. Annual is still going to be a better deal, but we know that customers may try it more frequently if it's a monthly plan. And that's what we're looking for. We know that once customers try, generally, they'll really like it. So we think that'll some other demographic groups as well.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Phil. Another comment on Prime. On your saturation question, keep in mind that even in the U.S., which is our most mature by years of launch, we still grew last year at 47% year-over-year membership growth, and we continue to make the program bett
componenttext: This is Phil. Another comment on Prime. On your saturation question, keep in mind that even in the U.S., which is our most mature by years of launch, we still grew last year at 47% year-over-year membership growth, and we continue to make the program better and better. I think the monthly offers are great for flexibility, give people a chance to try new ways, and we continue to add content, we continue to add selection. Prime Now is a huge benefit that didn't even exist 2 years ago. So all these things are making the program better, and we're still out trying to meet as many customers as possible. We're obviously very committed to driving Prime and in support of the company. Your question on China, the biggest thing to point to is more progress in selection on the Amazon Global Store. So this is our website -- this is the offer that allows Chinese customers to shop from the U.S. website, Amazon.com, with prices in RMB and with Chinese language pages. So it's focused on really items that may be hard to get. And Amazon is really trying to become the trusted source for many of these goods. And so really that's a big part of the focus. And if you've been tracking that number over time, we're now up over 10 million [ph] which is a good progress on that one.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ron Josey of JMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ron Josey of JMP Securities.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to go back to North America but this time just focused on margins. 5.5%, 5.4% margins, I think that's the highest level since maybe 2Q 2010. And resume the margin expansion we saw really from most of last year. So just hoping we could understand --
componenttext: I want to go back to North America but this time just focused on margins. 5.5%, 5.4% margins, I think that's the highest level since maybe 2Q 2010. And resume the margin expansion we saw really from most of last year. So just hoping we could understand -- help us understand a little bit more what's driving that. I'm sure it's the more mature Prime flywheel you mentioned that's happening in Europe, but is there anything else that's going on besides Prime flywheel, maybe more efficient shipping or things along those lines?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start. I think when you see the growth rate of the segment, the 27% and showing the success we're having with customers, when we grow at that clip we can do a lot of good things with it. We can, on the cost side we run our facilities more efficiently
componenttext: I'll start. I think when you see the growth rate of the segment, the 27% and showing the success we're having with customers, when we grow at that clip we can do a lot of good things with it. We can, on the cost side we run our facilities more efficiently and better. We can look to in-source something that we may have paid externally for. So there's a number of things that we can do that I think will show up on the bottom line. But principally, what we're trying to do now is again make the Prime experience as strong as possible for customers.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Phil. the other thing I would add to that is the margin you see in any quarter is really the output of kind of our rate of investment at some places and drive for efficiencies and others. And we're not really trying to optimize for any particular
componenttext: This is Phil. the other thing I would add to that is the margin you see in any quarter is really the output of kind of our rate of investment at some places and drive for efficiencies and others. And we're not really trying to optimize for any particular number in a given quarter. We're just trying to make the best decisions we can to grow long-term free cash flow per share. And so again, we're juggling the investment in places where we feel like we have long-term opportunity and where we need to invest with making sure we're getting continuously better in all other processes at the same time.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Our final question will come from Bob Peck of SunTrust.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones. Just back to India for a second. I was wondering if you could talk about the regulatory environment there, particularly how it pertains to Amazon Cloud Tail. And then number two on logistics. Could you talk about excess capacity in the
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones. Just back to India for a second. I was wondering if you could talk about the regulatory environment there, particularly how it pertains to Amazon Cloud Tail. And then number two on logistics. Could you talk about excess capacity in the just accessible dot Airfreight, et cetera? And would you ever entertain delivering other company's items, i.e., like a FedEx or UPS?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Phil. I'll take the India question. We're happy to see the recent clarifications, and we're happy to operate in any regime and so frankly, the more clarity the better.
componenttext: This is Phil. I'll take the India question. We're happy to see the recent clarifications, and we're happy to operate in any regime and so frankly, the more clarity the better.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on the logistics question, stepping back, the reason we add logistics capability and transportation capability is so we can serve our customers faster and faster delivery speeds. And with native add more of our own capacity to supplement our carr
componenttext: And then on the logistics question, stepping back, the reason we add logistics capability and transportation capability is so we can serve our customers faster and faster delivery speeds. And with native add more of our own capacity to supplement our carriers and our partners. They're still again great partners, have been and will continue to be for the future. But we see opportunities where we need to add additional capacity and we're filling those voids.
