componenttext: I have two. The first one on the echo. Maybe you can share at all on some of the most commonly used searches, how are consumers using the echo as [indiscernible] most commonly? And anything on uplift and uplift on purchase behavior from echo households? And the second one on Prime, on AWS margins, can you just walk through some of the puts and takes that have been driving the AWS margin expansion we've seen in the first half of this year? Is it utilization product mix, what's been driving the margin expansion?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, in echo, again, we continue to build out the list of devices launching the dot and tapped and Fire TV skills this past year. And now we have 1,900 third-party skills for the Aleksei, including new skills from Kayak, Lyft, NBC, Honeywell and mo
componenttext: Sure. Well, in echo, again, we continue to build out the list of devices launching the dot and tapped and Fire TV skills this past year. And now we have 1,900 third-party skills for the Aleksei, including new skills from Kayak, Lyft, NBC, Honeywell and more. So a lot of uses that we're seeing for echo, a lot ties into our Prime Music offering. It's just a great way to access Prime Music more and more the Amazon site. We don't have anything to disclose on physical orders from [indiscernible] orders through echo. On Amazon Web services margin, again, this was primarily due to efficiencies gained on or our infrastructure, better utilization, better cost out. There is a certainly a mix of products and services. I don't have a bridge for you on either that's helpful or hurtful, but these margins in AWS will fluctuate from quarter-to-quarter and that's what you're seeing but we're very happy with the year-over-year improvement.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mark Mahaney from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Mark Mahaney from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey Brian, could you give us some wise as to the revenue growth acceleration that you're seeing, a little more color about the revenue growth acceleration in North American retail and in international retail? I remember last quarter, you called out really
componenttext: Hey Brian, could you give us some wise as to the revenue growth acceleration that you're seeing, a little more color about the revenue growth acceleration in North American retail and in international retail? I remember last quarter, you called out really starting to see kind of critical mass tipping point, whatever the best word is, from Prime and from FBA and international markets. Is that what's continuing, I assume, to kind of drive that re-acceleration in any geographic country comments behind that?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, had the same buzz words for you, Mark. It's really the flywheel Prime is definitely working. It's simple as that. Low prices actually convenient continue to resonate with customers. Prime membership increases and selection through FBA makes Pri
componenttext: Sure. Yes, had the same buzz words for you, Mark. It's really the flywheel Prime is definitely working. It's simple as that. Low prices actually convenient continue to resonate with customers. Prime membership increases and selection through FBA makes Prime more valuable. So it's a bit as simple as that in the consumer business in North America and international. We are seeing great acceptance of Prime and usage of Prime benefits. We continue to expand the list of Prime benefits for customers to make it more valuable and none is more valuable than FBA, which we've talked a lot about the value of Prime to FBA and vice versa. FBA is bringing more [indiscernible] selection to Prime and then the growth of Prime and the type of customers that utilize Prime and their buying behavior is a great attraction for other FBA sellers. So that is essentially what we're seeing and we're certainly pleased with the customer response to those offers globally.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Youssef Squali from Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions, please. Brian, your operating income has come in stronger than expectations but more importantly, stronger than your own guidance, at least in the last couple of quarters. I was just wondering as you look back at where you guided relative t
componenttext: Two questions, please. Brian, your operating income has come in stronger than expectations but more importantly, stronger than your own guidance, at least in the last couple of quarters. I was just wondering as you look back at where you guided relative to actual, where do you think that delta was most pronounced? Why wouldn't we assume that may be, at least on the margin, the investment intensity in the business has may be decelerated a bit? And second, on Prime Video, just was wondering, considering what the main competitor there is doing, i.e. expanding aggressively around the world, you guys have been growing in a more measured manner, is that still the plan or are you guys interested in may be, instead of moving into few countries, kind of expand globally [indiscernible]?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me start with the second question first. So on Prime Video, again, we're very happy with the customer adoption of Prime Video and we know the customers love it, we like the results that we see, particularly with the free trial conversion, the re
componenttext: Sure. Let me start with the second question first. So on Prime Video, again, we're very happy with the customer adoption of Prime Video and we know the customers love it, we like the results that we see, particularly with the free trial conversion, the renewal rates for subscription. So it's clearly working. I mentioned earlier how we're doubling the investment rate in second half of the year versus the last year second half and we're tripling the Amazon originals content. That originals content, for TVs and movies, that content can be used globally. We've talked a bit about our Prime launch in India and alluded to the fact that we'll be having video soon in India, both local content and also Amazon originals. So stay tuned for that, many more to announce on that today. On the variance to guidance, what I'll say is we came in the very high end of our revenue guidance. I would say that our business model usually reacts well to high-volume as we get a really good leverage on our fixed expenses. So the best part of what we saw, very strong operating efficiencies as we hit essentially the highest end of our revenue guidance. But we do have a lot of diverse profit streams here at Amazon and a lot of investments going on at any point in time. I think I heard a question there about level of investment. We continue to invest heavily. In fact, I just called out a few things that are going to be stepping up in investment levels in Q3, mostly ops and digital content. So we continue to invest on behalf of customers, but we also work very hard, efficiently scaling the businesses that we have. So we take both roles very seriously around here, the best thing on the right -- in right things, seeing results on behalf of customers and also driving efficiencies. And there can be timing, quarter-to-quarter, the operating margin and levels of investment can fluctuate, but certainly, continue to expand.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Jason Helfstein with Oppenheimer.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is on for Jason Helfstein. Just on the AWS side, we've been hearing a lot of talk and especially around media reports that larger customers tend to use AWS, they might use Google and Microsoft in tandem in sort of a multi-cloud kind of architecture.
componenttext: This is on for Jason Helfstein. Just on the AWS side, we've been hearing a lot of talk and especially around media reports that larger customers tend to use AWS, they might use Google and Microsoft in tandem in sort of a multi-cloud kind of architecture. Just wondering your thoughts on how you see AWS fitting in the overall ecosystem and kind of your place longer-term in the ecosystem?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, first of all, we believe customers will choose AWS primarily for 3 factors: the functionality and pace of innovation that we bring to the table; our partner and customer ecosystem; and our experience. We've been in this business longer than an
componenttext: Sure. Well, first of all, we believe customers will choose AWS primarily for 3 factors: the functionality and pace of innovation that we bring to the table; our partner and customer ecosystem; and our experience. We've been in this business longer than anyone. Having said that, there are room, plenty of room for multiple vendors in this business. What we focus on is innovating on behalf of customers and expanding the geographic footprint to make our services more widely available. You can see us continuing to invest in things like new application services higher up the stack, additional technologies that will make integrating with AWS seamless for those companies that have a hybrid IT environment and then continue to add functionality for data, analytics, mobile, Internet of Things, machine offerings, things like that, that will add greater and greater value for AWS customers. And I would say, the rapid pace of innovation continues to stretch our lead in that dimension. We have had 422 new significant services and features added in the first half of this year at a faster pace than last year when we added 722 services and features. So we feel good about the business position we're in and our position with customers.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question from Colin Sebastian with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question from Colin Sebastian with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: As another follow-up in the margins, I was hoping you could comment on any impact from the investments in buildout of enhanced transportation capabilities, including the air cargo leases? And then secondly, I was hoping you could identify any categories w
componenttext: As another follow-up in the margins, I was hoping you could comment on any impact from the investments in buildout of enhanced transportation capabilities, including the air cargo leases? And then secondly, I was hoping you could identify any categories within EGM that are becoming more meaningful drivers of growth or at least are an increasing focus on the retail side?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. First on EGM, I will just say, the growth is across a lot of different products, none to exactly call out here and we think a lot of it is of course driven by the growth of Prime itself. EGM in North America grew 32%, which is higher than the r
componenttext: Yes, sure. First on EGM, I will just say, the growth is across a lot of different products, none to exactly call out here and we think a lot of it is of course driven by the growth of Prime itself. EGM in North America grew 32%, which is higher than the revenue growth rate and also grew 36% internationally. So when Prime customer -- when people join Prime, they are certainly buying EGM in strong quantity. So that continues to grow with the growth of the Prime program. On transportation, I think your question was about whether that's impacting our short-term results. No, the answer is no, we are certainly expanding our service offerings on the transportation side and we have been for many years, things like rotation centers and delivery methods. The plane deal that we were talking about is essentially planes that we're going to be leasing from other companies and you'll hear more about that as we go forward, but that is to essentially take on the demand for internal flights that we -- as we move product around. Certainly, will be well utilized.

componenttext: First, on FC buildout, is the cost of building centers scaling over time given the use of Kiva, other technologies or general learnings? Or are those costs still relatively consistent? And also, we noticed some device sellout in the next 4 to 5 weeks post Prime Day. Was this a bit of a planned inventory reduction for some of the devices or did volumes take you by surprise here?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will start with the second question. So I would just say, Prime Day had an enormous impact on the device business and devices were well featured and also well adopted by customers. So it was the largest device sales day that we've ever had and essential
componenttext: I will start with the second question. So I would just say, Prime Day had an enormous impact on the device business and devices were well featured and also well adopted by customers. So it was the largest device sales day that we've ever had and essentially, across all -- pretty much across all of our device types, readers, tablets, Fire TV and echo. And I'm sorry, your first question was around? Yes, the cost of fulfillment centers. Not disclosing that, we do continue to change our fulfillment centers. We changed, again, the automation, the size, the scale many times and we continue to learn and grow there. So no general trends I can point to on cost for fulfillment center to start up, but because they do vary in size and mission and some are -- have fully outfitted in using Amazon robotics, others, some [indiscernible] for economic reasons, maybe volume's not perfect for robot volume. But yes, I can't give you any real distinct trends there.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on Prime penetration, of course, we haven't released Prime subscription levels. We have talked about growth certainly globally and in North America. What I can tell you there is we still think there's a lot of room in Prime, a lot of -- we tailored pr
componenttext: And on Prime penetration, of course, we haven't released Prime subscription levels. We have talked about growth certainly globally and in North America. What I can tell you there is we still think there's a lot of room in Prime, a lot of -- we tailored programs to students, we've tailored video programs, we've rolled out monthly plans. We have plans related with grocery deliveries so there's a lot of different flavors of Prime and we are aggressively looking for a perfect Prime for everybody. We know that, again, when customers try Prime, they like it, so it's really just about getting them to try Prime and continuing to deliver great Prime benefits and great low prices and selection.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had two. First is a follow-up on the logistics topic. So in addition to the cargo planes you just mentioned for moving products around, you guys have registered and received U.S. Maritime license to operate as a freight forwarder and you recently a
componenttext: I just had two. First is a follow-up on the logistics topic. So in addition to the cargo planes you just mentioned for moving products around, you guys have registered and received U.S. Maritime license to operate as a freight forwarder and you recently announced this partnership with the U.K. for drone delivery that you've been working on for a couple of years so I guess at a high level, can you just talk about how the overall logistic strategy is evolving from trucks and fulfillment centers to incorporate some of these new methods and how that might impact your unit costs going forward? And then the second question is on AWS, you continue to post really strong results and [indiscernible] take to a lot of customers across lots of different verticals. Just a high level, what percent of enterprise workloads do you think have shifted to the public cloud at this stage? Is it low single digits? Mid-single digits? And any color there on where we are in terms of penetration in the space?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ross, this is Darren. Let me take that first question. On Prime Air in the U.K., we've been working with and developing Prime Air for some time to develop a rapid delivery system that safe, environmentally sound and it really enhances the services that we
componenttext: Ross, this is Darren. Let me take that first question. On Prime Air in the U.K., we've been working with and developing Prime Air for some time to develop a rapid delivery system that safe, environmentally sound and it really enhances the services that we provide for millions of customers and we're extremely happy to partner with the U.K. government to advance the safe use of drones for small parcel delivery. This is providing us with information to try new methods in this space, including beyond line of sight operation, sense and avoid technologies and flights where 1 person operates multiple drones. So we definitely appreciate the pragmatic and forward-looking approach on this topic with the U.K. and we're going to continue to work with regulators and policymakers in many countries, including the U.S., so we're excited about there. As for the ocean going licenses, we haven't commented on that today.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: As far as AWS, essentially, penetration question you asked, we think still very early again. We like our position, our industry-leading position in the cloud space and we're working on things that would [indiscernible] more and more customers to accelerate their cloud conversion, the lower prices and services that we offer and as I said, we'll work on things that will make it easier and easier for customers to work with us with their hybrid data centers or transfer their volume to us.

componenttext: Eric, this is Darren. I'll take the second question on China. So we continue to operate well in China. So still early days and some of those experiments that we're doing, but we're seeing good traction on those things and we like them.

So maybe you can just talk about the opportunities and the challenges that we're seeing in their market. And second, it was impressive [indiscernible] $500 million of incremental capital in Italy. headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So India, we're very encouraged by what we've seen so far in India, both with customers and also sellers as the third-party seller market. You heard that we launched the Prime program this week which will be a whole new experience for Indian custome
componenttext: Sure. So India, we're very encouraged by what we've seen so far in India, both with customers and also sellers as the third-party seller market. You heard that we launched the Prime program this week which will be a whole new experience for Indian customers. In [indiscernible] cities will now have unlimited free 1-day and 2-day delivery and we also mentioned that Prime Video is coming there, both India and global content. We're also starting to see exclusive online sales partnerships. Recently, we've had selected -- we've had partnerships with Motorola, Samsung, Lenovo and select phones. But more importantly, again, we really like the opportunity in India. We like the initial results that we see from customers and also sellers. We really like our team there. We have a great team of Amazonian's who's been very inventive in India. Every time there's an obstacle or something that's different from the U.S. or another major business [indiscernible] bent around it, whether it's shipping method or a payment method or whatever. So very creative and customer's response has been really strong. So we are very excited about the Prime program. We think we'll enter into a new chapter in India and we've seen great success in every country in the world that we've launched Prime and we feel there's going to be no different. So we're looking forward to seeing what we can do on behalf of the Indian customer.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Victor, this is Darren. On Italy, yes, we continue to invest in Italy and really throughout Europe to keep pace with the strong customer demand we see. Since opening Italy in 2010, we've invested over EUR 450 million and created 1,700 jobs in Italy an
componenttext: And Victor, this is Darren. On Italy, yes, we continue to invest in Italy and really throughout Europe to keep pace with the strong customer demand we see. Since opening Italy in 2010, we've invested over EUR 450 million and created 1,700 jobs in Italy and this increased investment will be to add future FC [indiscernible] and other infrastructure assets. So yes, this is really to support both the customers that we have there in Italy and throughout Europe and we'll continue to invest in the coming years.

componenttext: Thank you for standing by. Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Amazon.com Q2 2016 Financial Results Teleconference. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to our Q2 2016 financial results conference call. Joining us today is Brian Olsavsky, our CFO. We will be available for questions after our prepared remarks. The following discussion and the responses to your questions reflect managem
componenttext:
Hello, and welcome to our Q2 2016 financial results conference call. Joining us today is Brian Olsavsky, our CFO. We will be available for questions after our prepared remarks. 
The following discussion and the responses to your questions reflect management's views as of today, July 28, 2016, only and will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially. Additional information about factors that could potentially impact our financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, including our most recent annual report on Form 10-K and subsequent filings. As you listen to today's conference call, we encourage you to have our press release in front of you, which includes our financial results, as well as metrics and commentary on the quarter. 
During this call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures in our press release, slides accompanying this webcast and our filings with the SEC, each of which is posted on our IR website. You will find additional disclosures regarding these non-GAAP measures, including reconciliations of these measures with comparable GAAP measures. Please note, unless otherwise stated, all comparisons in this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2015.
Now I'll turn the call over to Brian.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Darin. I'll begin with comments on our second quarter financial results. Trailing 12 months operating cash flow increased 42% to $12.7 billion. Trailing 12 months free cash flow increased to $7.3 billion, up from $4.4 billion. Trailing 12 months
componenttext:
Thanks, Darin. I'll begin with comments on our second quarter financial results. 
Trailing 12 months operating cash flow increased 42% to $12.7 billion. Trailing 12 months free cash flow increased to $7.3 billion, up from $4.4 billion. Trailing 12 months free cash flow less lease principal repayments increased to $3.9 billion, up from $2.4 billion. Trailing 12 months free cash flow less finance lease principal repayments and assets acquired under capital leases increased to $2.5 billion, up from an outflow of $492 million. Worldwide revenue increased 31% to $30.4 billion, or 30%, excluding the $166 million favorable impact from year-over-year changes in foreign exchange. Worldwide paid unit growth was 28%. Worldwide seller units represented 49% of paid units.
Now I'll talk about our segment result. North America revenue grew 28% to $17.7 billion. North America operating income was $702 million, a 4% operating margin compared with $348 million in the prior year. This includes $5 million of favorable impact from foreign exchange. International revenue grew 30% to $9.8 billion. Excluding the $184 million year-over-year favorable foreign exchange impact, revenue growth was 28%. International operating loss was $135 million compared with a loss of $189 million in the prior year. This includes $40 million of favorable impact from foreign exchange. 
Amazon Web Services revenue grew 58%, $2.9 billion. Amazon Web Services operating income was $718 million, a 24.9% operating margin compared with $305 million in the prior year. Our operating income was $1.3 billion or 4.2% of revenue, up approximately 220 basis points year-over-year. This includes $45 million of favorable impact from foreign exchange. Net income was $857 million or $1.78 per diluted share compared with a net income of $92 million or $0.19 per diluted share.
I'll conclude my portion of today's call with guidance. For Q3 2016, we expect net sales of between $31 billion and $33.5 billion, or growth of between 22% and 32%. This guidance anticipates approximately 30 basis points of favorable impact from foreign exchange rate. Operating income to be between $50 million and $650 million compared with $406 million in third quarter 2015. 
We're grateful to our customers and remain heads-down focused on driving better customer experience. We believe putting customers first is the only reliable way to create lasting value for shareholders. 
Thanks. And with that, I'll hand it back to Darin.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brian. Before we move to questions, I need to remind you that our guidance incorporates the order trends that we've seen to-date and what we believe to be appropriate assumption. Our results are inherently unpredictable and may be materially af
componenttext:
Thank you, Brian. Before we move to questions, I need to remind you that our guidance incorporates the order trends that we've seen to-date and what we believe to be appropriate assumption. Our results are inherently unpredictable and may be materially affected by many factors, including fluctuations in foreign exchange rates, changes in global economic conditions and customer spending, world events, the rate of growth of the Internet, online commerce and cloud services and the various factors detailed in our filings with the SEC. Our guidance also assumes that we don't conclude any additional business acquisitions, investment, restructurings or legal settlements and that foreign exchange rates remain approximately where they have been recently. It is not possible to accurately predict demand for our goods and services, and therefore, our actual results could differ materially from our guidance.
With that, let's move to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, please remind our listeners how to initiate a question.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Mark May of Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Mark May of Citi.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've noticed some data points out there that suggest that you're kind of accelerating your build out of fulfillment capacity in North America, and obviously, also in India. Can you give us a sense of what sort of impact that, that might have in the near
componenttext: We've noticed some data points out there that suggest that you're kind of accelerating your build out of fulfillment capacity in North America, and obviously, also in India. Can you give us a sense of what sort of impact that, that might have in the near to midterm on your CapEx, depreciation, and ultimately, CSOI, especially as it relates to your Q3 guidance? And then just kind of a maintenance question, how much is FX impacting your Q3 guidance?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks, Mark. Yes, let me talk a little bit about guidance and I'll incorporate the answer to the fulfillment question. So you'll notice on the top line guidance of $31 billion to $33.5 billion, or 22% to 32% growth incorporates the Prime Day result
componenttext: Okay, thanks, Mark. Yes, let me talk a little bit about guidance and I'll incorporate the answer to the fulfillment question. So you'll notice on the top line guidance of $31 billion to $33.5 billion, or 22% to 32% growth incorporates the Prime Day results, and I can talk more about that later, but Prime Day was very successful for us. It was up 60% on a worldwide-basis over the prior year and it was also a record day for Amazon devices, as well sellers and customers alike. In the bottom line, you'll need to remember that Q3 is typically a low -- lower operating income quarter as we prepare for Q4, the holiday peak. It's a little bit more exaggerated this year in that we're opening 18 fulfillment centers this quarter. To put that in perspective, we launched 6 in Q3 of last year. This will bring us up to 21 net FCs for the year by the end of Q3 and that compares with 10 fulfillment centers for the first 3 quarters of last year on a net basis. So why we expanding so much? If you remember back to Q4 and the capacity constraints we had in Q4, primarily due to really strong FBA growth, we talked a lot in the Q4 call about the operational cost of that in Q4, customers well taken care of, but we had additional fulfillment costs from being so tight in capacity. This year, with that in mind and then knowing that our growth rate is actually accelerating on a unit basis, we're -- Q2 with 28% unit growth for paid units, but fulfilled by -- units Fulfilled by Amazon is much higher than that due to the growth of Prime and FBA. That compares with last year in Q2 when we saw 22% unit growth, or 600 basis points faster growth in Q2 this year than last year and that 22% last year trended at 26% in Q4. So it ramped up in the back end of the year. So a lot of data points there, but the bottom line is that there is a large step up in the amount of fulfillment capacity in Q2 -- excuse me, Q3 versus Q2. There's couple of other factors while I'm added for guidance. We're also nearly doubling our content spend in the second half of this year versus the second half of 2015. We have a great slate of new Amazon originals coming out later this year, both in the U.S. and internationally, and we're nearly tripling our number of new Amazon original shows -- TV shows and movies compared with the second half of last year. There are other investments, certainly, that are increasing sequentially. I point to India and AWS, but primarily the 2 biggest issues in Q3 guidance, I would say, are the operational ramp and also the increase in the digital content spend.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Mark, to follow up on the other question. Our net sales guidance anticipates approximately 30 basis points of favorable impact from foreign exchange rates.
componenttext: And Mark, to follow up on the other question. Our net sales guidance anticipates approximately 30 basis points of favorable impact from foreign exchange rates.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Douglas Anmuth from JPMorgan.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to go back to Prime Day for a minute. I didn't hear any commentary around new Prime members, in particular. Obviously, a lot of other metrics that you gave, but hoping you could provide a little bit more color around that. And then also, is
componenttext: I just wanted to go back to Prime Day for a minute. I didn't hear any commentary around new Prime members, in particular. Obviously, a lot of other metrics that you gave, but hoping you could provide a little bit more color around that. And then also, is there anything else that kind of stood out in terms of what you learned around operations and systems ahead of the holiday season? And then just going back to the 3Q guide, what's the right way for us to think about stock-based comp in the third quarter? And if we looked at your 2Q numbers, is that kind of a fair assumption for what you're thinking about?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, let me circle back on Prime Day. So, again, it was the biggest global day ever for Amazon and was up 60% on a order product sales basis versus Prime Day 2015. It was record day for Amazon devices. It was a great day for small businesses and sellers.
componenttext: Sure, let me circle back on Prime Day. So, again, it was the biggest global day ever for Amazon and was up 60% on a order product sales basis versus Prime Day 2015. It was record day for Amazon devices. It was a great day for small businesses and sellers. We saw great year-over-year improvement in their sales, and more importantly, it's a great day for customers globally. They saved over double what they'd saved in Prime Day 2015. So we're very pleased with the results of Prime Day and the impact of Prime Day is factored into this guidance. As far as new customers and new Prime members, we're not disclosing that, but suffice to say that it was a great day both existing Prime members and also new customers who were trying us out for the first time.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the stock-based compensation, you recall, beginning in Q1 this year, we began allocating stock-based compensation and other operating expense to our North America, international and AWS segments. So we're including that in our guidance on operating
componenttext: And on the stock-based compensation, you recall, beginning in Q1 this year, we began allocating stock-based compensation and other operating expense to our North America, international and AWS segments. So we're including that in our guidance on operating income and have not separately guided to stock-based comp and other income expense this quarter.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gene Munster with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gene Munster with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of questions, the customer account, can you give us a bit of guidance on that? And then also talk about the theme of automated consumption, and separately, the importance of Prime Now and how you can kind of grow those SKUs?
componenttext: In terms of questions, the customer account, can you give us a bit of guidance on that? And then also talk about the theme of automated consumption, and separately, the importance of Prime Now and how you can kind of grow those SKUs?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gene, this is Darin. I'll start with the customer accounts. As we noted, again, on our Q1 release, our active customer accounts exceeded 300 million. However, today, we're not going to update that number.
componenttext: Gene, this is Darin. I'll start with the customer accounts. As we noted, again, on our Q1 release, our active customer accounts exceeded 300 million. However, today, we're not going to update that number.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: To your question on Prime Now. So I will point out, Prime Now is now in more than 40 metro areas worldwide. In the past quarter, we expanded further internationally to Germany, Spain and France, so it's a global program. Again, offering free 2-hour delive
componenttext: To your question on Prime Now. So I will point out, Prime Now is now in more than 40 metro areas worldwide. In the past quarter, we expanded further internationally to Germany, Spain and France, so it's a global program. Again, offering free 2-hour delivery on tens of thousands of items. We also have in the same vein of, I think, what you called, may be automated consumption, the same day has expanded, now we've added 11 metro areas to bring the total to 27 metro areas that are qualified for same day. So, yes, we think this is a important part of our Prime offering. We know customers love it. We're very happy with their order patterns from Prime Now and very happy with it. Of course, we do always talk about what was usually get asked about profitability, and it is a very hard service to deliver and make money on, but we know customers love it, and we're in a great position to do this because of our long-term approach, our drive of greater efficiencies and our proximity to the customer with our vast global FC network.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Heath Terry from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Heath Terry from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering as it relates to the Q3 guidance, can you give us a bit of a sense of just how we should think about margins in the AWS business, especially, as the next 8 availability zones roll out, presumably that kind of increase in capacity, lik
componenttext: I was just wondering as it relates to the Q3 guidance, can you give us a bit of a sense of just how we should think about margins in the AWS business, especially, as the next 8 availability zones roll out, presumably that kind of increase in capacity, likely it has an impact on margins. But would appreciate sort of any direction you can share on how to think about that?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Now the -- we don't give -- obviously, we don't give segment-based guidance, but to your question about AWS, we actually see 9 availability zones 4 regions coming out in the next -- in the coming year. The impact on short-term is pretty much indisti
componenttext: Sure. Now the -- we don't give -- obviously, we don't give segment-based guidance, but to your question about AWS, we actually see 9 availability zones 4 regions coming out in the next -- in the coming year. The impact on short-term is pretty much indistinguishable from the growth that we're seeing in our expansion of our base customers in our existing regions. So we don't see a large step up from the addition of new regions relative to the large and rapid growth in the business itself. We do think that it does pay benefits both for ourselves and for our customers because of the expansion, and we're happy to added the region in Mumbai this past quarter. We think, when we expand geographically, existing customers will run more their workloads on AWS. Sometimes they have local latency concerns or security issues that require them to run things in their country, so that helps, and we also open up to new customers when we add these regions. So not a large impact on Q3 guidance, but certainly, exciting investment for our customer base.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Carlos Kirjner with Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Carlos Kirjner with Bernstein.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions, if I may. As I look at your tech and content expense as a percentage of revenues, we see year-on-year decline for the last 2 quarters, which is something we hadn't seen since mid-2010, and of course, this is reflected in the AWS margins. Ca
componenttext: Two questions, if I may. As I look at your tech and content expense as a percentage of revenues, we see year-on-year decline for the last 2 quarters, which is something we hadn't seen since mid-2010, and of course, this is reflected in the AWS margins. Can you help us understand what has driven this significant change in relative trajectory in tech and content expenses? And the second question is, why is it that the rate at which you are deploying Prime Now is so much greater or faster than the rate at which you are deploying a Fresh? Now what's different between them? And how is it that -- now you are deploying Fresh in new markets, but not as fast as Prime Now and what drives the difference?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. On tech and content, that's going to be a combination of our people cost related to many areas of the website and also the infrastructure costs to run it, at both the Amazon Web Services and also the Amazon site. We've been seeing some great efficie
componenttext: Sure. On tech and content, that's going to be a combination of our people cost related to many areas of the website and also the infrastructure costs to run it, at both the Amazon Web Services and also the Amazon site. We've been seeing some great efficiencies in our infrastructure, both internally as Amazon and also as part of AWS. We have great people working on, not only better efficiency, but also driving costs out of our acquisition prices. So there is a lot of great work going on there. I think that's what you're seeing reflected in the tech and content line. Again, this can fluctuate quarter-to-quarter, but we are happy with the current trend and you'll see it in the AWS margins. On Prime Now versus Fresh, the -- they are separate -- sorry. The -- we'll point out in Q2 that we added London and Boston as 2 new sites in London for AmazonFresh and that was the first international location. But we've been running AmazonFresh for 7 years -- excuse me, since 2007 in Seattle, and what you've seen as we've been testing the model, we've been expanding in North America, and more so, we've been expanding within the cities that we're in, adding ZIP Codes, adding additional customers. So the move into Boston and also now to London give us some really good data points. And as -- it's a great customer feature for the Prime offering. Prime Now is a little bit easier to build up from scratch, I would say. It has a different purpose, although some of the products overlap. Again, this is more about immediacy of 1-hour and 2-hour delivery of a curated list of important products that people needed in short period of time. So they have different roles. Some of the products overlap, of course, but we're happy with both, and we think that customers like both of them.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Brian Nowak from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from Brian Nowak from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have two. The first one is on the Echo. Maybe you can share at all on some of the most commonly used searches, how are consumers using the Echo as of now most commonly? And then anything on uplift in purchase behavior from Echo households? And the secon
componenttext: I have two. The first one is on the Echo. Maybe you can share at all on some of the most commonly used searches, how are consumers using the Echo as of now most commonly? And then anything on uplift in purchase behavior from Echo households? And the second one on Prime, on AWS margins, can you just walk us through some of the puts and takes that have been driving the AWS margin expansion we've seen in the first half of this year? Is it utilization product mix? What's been driving the margin expansion?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, in Echo, again, we continued to build out the list of devices launching the Dot and Tab and Fire TV skills this past year. And now we have 1,900 third-party skills for the Aleksei, including new skills from Kayak, Lyft, NBC, Honeywell and more
componenttext: Sure. Well, in Echo, again, we continued to build out the list of devices launching the Dot and Tab and Fire TV skills this past year. And now we have 1,900 third-party skills for the Aleksei, including new skills from Kayak, Lyft, NBC, Honeywell and more. So there's a lot of uses that we're seeing for Echo, a lot ties into our Prime Music offering. It's just a great way to access Prime Music and more and more the Amazon site. We don't have anything to disclose on physical orders from -- orders through Echo. On Amazon Web Services margin, again, this was primarily due to efficiencies gained on or our infrastructure, better utilization, better cost out. There is a certainly a mix of products and services. I don't have a bridge for you on whether that it's helpful or hurtful, but these margins in AWS will fluctuate from quarter-to-quarter and that's what you're seeing, but we're very happy with the year-over-year improvement.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Mark Mahaney from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Next question is from Mark Mahaney from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, could you give us some wise, as to the revenue growth acceleration that you're seeing, a little more color about the revenue growth acceleration in North American retail and in international retail? I remember last quarter, you called out really st
componenttext: Brian, could you give us some wise, as to the revenue growth acceleration that you're seeing, a little more color about the revenue growth acceleration in North American retail and in international retail? I remember last quarter, you called out really starting to see kind of critical mass tipping point, whatever the buzzword it is, from Prime and from FBA and international markets. Is that what's continuing, I assume, to kind of drive that reacceleration in any geographic country comments behind that?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, I had the same buzzwords for you, Mark. It's really the flywheel Prime is definitely working. It's simple as that. The low prices, vast selection and convenience continue to resonate with customers. Prime membership increases and selection thro
componenttext: Sure. Yes, I had the same buzzwords for you, Mark. It's really the flywheel Prime is definitely working. It's simple as that. The low prices, vast selection and convenience continue to resonate with customers. Prime membership increases and selection through FBA makes Prime more valuable. So it's a bit as simple as that in the consumer business in North America and international. We are seeing great acceptance of Prime and usage of Prime benefits. We continue to expand the list of Prime benefits for customers to make it more valuable and none is more valuable than FBA, which we've talked a lot about the value of Prime to FBA and vice versa. FBA is bringing more Prime -- multiple selection to Prime and then the growth of Prime and the type of customers that utilize Prime and their buying behavior is a great attraction for other FBA sellers. So that is essentially what we are seeing, and we're certainly pleased with the customer response to those offers globally.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Youssef Squali from Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Youssef Squali from Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions, please. Brian, your operating income has been come in stronger than expectations, but more importantly, stronger than your own guidance, at least in the last couple of quarters. I was just wondering as you look back at where you guided rela
componenttext: Two questions, please. Brian, your operating income has been come in stronger than expectations, but more importantly, stronger than your own guidance, at least in the last couple of quarters. I was just wondering as you look back at where you guided relative to actual, where do you think that delta was most pronounced? Why wouldn't we assume that maybe, at least on the margin, the investment intensity in the business has maybe decelerated a bit? And second, on Prime Video, just I was wondering, considering what the main competitor there is doing, i.e. expanding aggressively around the world, you guys have been growing in a more measured manner. Is that still the plan? Or are you guys interested in maybe, instead of moving into few countries, kind of expand globally in one fell swoop?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me start with the second question first. So on Prime Video, again, we're very happy with the customer adoption of Prime Video, and we know the customers love it, like the results that we see, particularly with the free trial conversion, the rene
componenttext: Sure. Let me start with the second question first. So on Prime Video, again, we're very happy with the customer adoption of Prime Video, and we know the customers love it, like the results that we see, particularly with the free trial conversion, the renewal rates for subscription. So it's clearly working. I mentioned earlier how we're doubling the investment rate in second half of the year versus the last year second half, and we're tripling the Amazon originals content. That originals content, for TVs and movies, that content can be used globally. We've talked a bit about our Prime launch in India and alluded to the fact that we'll be having video soon in India, both local content and also Amazon originals. So stay tuned for that, I don't have anymore to announce on that today. On the variance to guidance, what I'll say is, we came into very high end of our revenue guidance. I would say that our business model usually reacts well to high-volume, as we get a really good leverage on our fixed expenses. So that's part of what we saw, very strong operating efficiencies as we hit, essentially the highest end of our revenue guidance. But we do have a lot of diverse profit streams here at Amazon and a lot of investments going on at any point in time. I think I heard a question there about levels of investment. We continue to invest heavily. In fact, I just called out a few things that are going to be stepping up in investment levels in Q3, mostly ops and digital content. So we continue to invest on behalf of customers, but we also work very hard at efficiencies in scaling the businesses that we have. So we take both roles very seriously around here, best thing on the right -- in the right things, seeing results on behalf of customers and also driving efficiencies. And there can be timing, quarter-to-quarter, the operating margin and levels of investment can fluctuate, but certainly, continued to expand.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jason Helfstein with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jason Helfstein with Oppenheimer.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ray McDonough on for Jason Helfstein. Just on the AWS side, we've been hearing a lot of talk and especially lot of media reports that larger customers tend to use AWS, they might use Google and Microsoft Azure in tandem in sort of a multi-cloud ki
componenttext: This is Ray McDonough on for Jason Helfstein. Just on the AWS side, we've been hearing a lot of talk and especially lot of media reports that larger customers tend to use AWS, they might use Google and Microsoft Azure in tandem in sort of a multi-cloud kind of architecture. Just wondering your thoughts on how you see AWS fitting in the overall ecosystem and kind of your place longer-term in the ecosystem?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, first of all, we believe customers will choose AWS primarily for 3 factors: the functionality and pace of innovation that we bring to the table; our partner and customer ecosystem; and our experience. We've been in this business longer than an
componenttext: Sure. Well, first of all, we believe customers will choose AWS primarily for 3 factors: the functionality and pace of innovation that we bring to the table; our partner and customer ecosystem; and our experience. We've been in this business longer than anyone. Having said that, there are room -- plenty of room for multiple vendors in this business. What we focus on is innovating on behalf of customers and expanding the geographic footprint to make our services more widely available. You can see us continuing to invest in things like new application services higher up the stack, additional technologies that will make integrating with AWS seamless for those companies that have a hybrid IT environment and then continue to add functionality for data, analytics, mobile, Internet of Things, machine learning offerings, things like that, that will add greater and greater value for AWS customers. And I would say, the rapid pace of innovation continues to stretch our lead in that dimension. We have had 422 new significant services and features added in the first half of this year, that's a faster pace than last year when we added 722 services and features. So we feel good about the business, the position we're in and our position with customers.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question from Colin Sebastian with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question from Colin Sebastian with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: As another follow-up on the margins, I was hoping you could comment on any impact from the investments in build-out of enhanced transportation capabilities, including the air cargo leases? And then secondly, I was hoping you could identify any categories
componenttext: As another follow-up on the margins, I was hoping you could comment on any impact from the investments in build-out of enhanced transportation capabilities, including the air cargo leases? And then secondly, I was hoping you could identify any categories within EGMs that are becoming more meaningful drivers of growth or at least are an increasing focus on the retail side?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. First on EGM. I will just say, the growth is across a lot of different products, none to exactly call out here, and we think that a lot of it is, of course, driven by the growth of Prime itself. EGM in North America grew 32%, which was higher t
componenttext: Yes, sure. First on EGM. I will just say, the growth is across a lot of different products, none to exactly call out here, and we think that a lot of it is, of course, driven by the growth of Prime itself. EGM in North America grew 32%, which was higher than the revenue growth rate and also grew 36% internationally. So when Prime customer -- when people join Prime, they are certainly buying EGM in strong quantity. So that continues to grow with the growth of the Prime program. On transportation, I think your question was about whether that's impacting our short-term results. No, the answer is no. We are certainly expanding our service offerings on the transportation side, and we have been for many years, things like sortation centers and delivery methods. The plane deal that we were talking about is essentially planes that we're going to be leasing from other companies and you'll hear more about that as we go forward, but that is to essentially take on the demand for internal flights that we -- as we move product around, certainly, will be well utilized.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Pitz from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Pitz from Jefferies.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, on FC buildout, is the cost of building centers scaling over time given the use of Kiva, other technologies or general learnings? Or are those costs still relatively consistent? And also, we noticed some device sellout in the next 4 to 5 weeks post
componenttext: First, on FC buildout, is the cost of building centers scaling over time given the use of Kiva, other technologies or general learnings? Or are those costs still relatively consistent? And also, we noticed some device sellout in the next 4 to 5 weeks post Prime Day. Was this a bit of a planned inventory reduction for some of the devices or did volumes take you by surprise here?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will start with the second question. So I would just say, Prime Day had a enormous impact on the device business and devices were well featured and also well adopted by customers. So it was the largest device sales day that we've ever had, and essential
componenttext: I will start with the second question. So I would just say, Prime Day had a enormous impact on the device business and devices were well featured and also well adopted by customers. So it was the largest device sales day that we've ever had, and essentially, across all -- pretty much across all of our device types, e-readers, tablets, Fire TV and Echo. And I'm sorry, your first question was around the cost of fulfillment centers. Not disclosing that that -- we do continue to change our fulfillment centers. We've changed, again, the automation, the size, the scale many times, and we continue to learn and grow there. So no general trends I can point to on cost for fulfillment center to start up, but because they do vary in size and mission and some are -- have fully outfitted in using Amazon robotics, others -- some don't for economic reasons, maybe the volume's not perfect for robot volume. But yes, I can't give you any real distinct trends there.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Justin Post from Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is from Justin Post from Merrill Lynch.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First on the customers, I'm guessing -- I'm wondering why you aren't giving the number, a lot of people use it for their models. And then second thing, when you look at the U.S. Prime penetration versus total U.S. customers, how do you feel about that? An
componenttext: First on the customers, I'm guessing -- I'm wondering why you aren't giving the number, a lot of people use it for their models. And then second thing, when you look at the U.S. Prime penetration versus total U.S. customers, how do you feel about that? And do you think there's still a lot of room for Prime growth in the U.S.?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Justin, this is Darin. I'll comment on the customer accounts, again. We may consider updating that in the future, but really we encourage you and our investors to look at our free cash flow measures, our revenue and our GAAP operating profits, and so our
componenttext: Justin, this is Darin. I'll comment on the customer accounts, again. We may consider updating that in the future, but really we encourage you and our investors to look at our free cash flow measures, our revenue and our GAAP operating profits, and so our customer purchasing behavior can vary.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on Prime penetration, of course, we haven't released Prime subscription levels. We have talked about growth, certainly, globally and in North America. What I can tell you there is, we still think there's a lot of room in Prime, a lot of -- we tailored
componenttext: And on Prime penetration, of course, we haven't released Prime subscription levels. We have talked about growth, certainly, globally and in North America. What I can tell you there is, we still think there's a lot of room in Prime, a lot of -- we tailored programs to students, we've tailored video programs, we've rolled out monthly plans. We have plans related with grocery deliveries, so there's a lot of different flavors of Prime, and we are aggressively looking for a perfect Prime for everybody. We know that, again, when customers try Prime, they like it, so it's really just about getting them to try Prime and continuing to deliver great Prime benefits and great low prices and selection.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ross Sandler from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ross Sandler from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had two. First is a followup on the logistics topic. So in addition to the cargo planes you just mentioned for -- in that, we're moving products around, you guys have registered and received a U.S. Maritime license to operate as a freight forwarder
componenttext: I just had two. First is a followup on the logistics topic. So in addition to the cargo planes you just mentioned for -- in that, we're moving products around, you guys have registered and received a U.S. Maritime license to operate as a freight forwarder, and you recently announced this partnership with the U.K. for drone delivery that you've been working on for a couple of years. So I guess at a high level, can you just talk about how the overall logistic strategy is evolving from trucks and fulfillment centers to incorporate some of these new methods and how that might impact your unit costs going forward? And then the second question is on AWS, so you continue to post really strong results, and you guys obviously talk to a lot of customers across lots of different verticals. Just a high level, what percent of enterprise workloads do you think have shifted to the public cloud at this stage? Is it low single digits or mid-single digits? And any color there on where we are in terms of penetration in the space?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So thank you, Ross. Let me -- this is Darin. Let me take that first question. On Prime Air in the U.K., we've been working with and developing Prime Air for some time to develop a rapid delivery system that is safe, environmentally sound and it really enh
componenttext: So thank you, Ross. Let me -- this is Darin. Let me take that first question. On Prime Air in the U.K., we've been working with and developing Prime Air for some time to develop a rapid delivery system that is safe, environmentally sound and it really enhances the services that we provide for millions of customers. And we're extremely happy to partner with the U.K. government to advance the safe use of drones for small parcel delivery. This is providing us with permission to trial new methods in this space, including beyond line-of-sight operation, sensing and BYOD technologies and flights where one person operates multiple drones. So we definitely appreciate the pragmatic and forward-looking approach on this topic with the U.K, and we're going to continue to work with regulators and policymakers in many countries, including the U.S., so we're excited about there. As for the Ocean-going licenses, we have no comment on that today.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as AWS, essentially, penetration question you asked, we think still very early again. We like our position, our industry-leading position in the cloud space, and we're working on things that would sent more and more customers to accelerate their cl
componenttext: As far as AWS, essentially, penetration question you asked, we think still very early again. We like our position, our industry-leading position in the cloud space, and we're working on things that would sent more and more customers to accelerate their cloud conversion, the lower prices and services that we offer. And as I said, we'll work on things that will make it easier and easier for customers to work with us with their hybrid data centers or transfer their volume to us.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Eric Sheridan from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Eric Sheridan from UBS.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe one clarification and one big picture topic. On the clarification, I appreciate the disclosure on content and how that will double year-on-year in the second half. For purposes of just making sure we sort of can understand the trajectory, is there a
componenttext: Maybe one clarification and one big picture topic. On the clarification, I appreciate the disclosure on content and how that will double year-on-year in the second half. For purposes of just making sure we sort of can understand the trajectory, is there any way to frame it within second half of this year versus first half of this year just so we can sort of try to triangulate on a gross margin basis from the content spend? And the bigger picture topic would be China, hasn't come up yet on the call. I wanted to understand your latest thoughts there, on either the competitive landscape relative positioning in China and how you think about investments in China?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, this is Darin. I'll take the second question on China. So we continued to operate well in China. We see China as a -- and the way we're approaching China as a way to trusted avenue for our Chinese customers to access authentic international brands,
componenttext: Eric, this is Darin. I'll take the second question on China. So we continued to operate well in China. We see China as a -- and the way we're approaching China as a way to trusted avenue for our Chinese customers to access authentic international brands, and we'll focus on those global brands and bringing those to Chinese customers. Offerings like the Amazon global store where Chinese customers can access those international brands on the China website and have them ship directly to their houses is something we're focused on. So, yes, still early days in some of those experiments that we're doing, but we were seeing good traction on those things and we like that.

componenttext: Yes. And on the content spend, I think the only data point I can give you is probably [indiscernible] data point at this point. But we spent $1.3 billion in 2014 and that's the last number that we disclosed, and we continue to add content. The best I can give you at this point is that it will be double -- nearly double what we spent in the second half of 2015.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I'll just ask a question about India. You called out India was -- you had the most visited e-commerce site as well as the most downloaded mobile app, and you also launched Prime. So maybe you can just talk about the opportunities and the challenges
componenttext: Maybe I'll just ask a question about India. You called out India was -- you had the most visited e-commerce site as well as the most downloaded mobile app, and you also launched Prime. So maybe you can just talk about the opportunities and the challenges that you're seeing in that market. And second, there was some press report that you invested about $500 million of incremental capital in Italy. I was wondering what are you seeing in that market that justifies that level of investment?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So India, we're very encouraged by what we've seen so far in India, both with customers and also sellers that are today third-party seller market. You heard that we launched the Prime program this week, which will be a whole new experience for India
componenttext: Sure. So India, we're very encouraged by what we've seen so far in India, both with customers and also sellers that are today third-party seller market. You heard that we launched the Prime program this week, which will be a whole new experience for Indian customers. In hundreds of cities we'll now have unlimited free 1-day and 2-day delivery, and we also mentioned that Prime Video is coming there, both Indian and global content. We're also starting to see exclusive online sales partnerships. Recently, we've got partnerships with Motorola, Samsung, Lenovo on select phones. But more importantly, again, we really like the opportunity in India. We like the initial results that we see from customers and also sellers. We really like our team there. We have a great team of Amazonian's who's been very inventive in India. Every time there's an obstacle or something that's different from the U.S. or another major business still advance around it, whether it's shipping method or a payment method or whatever. So very creative and the customers' response has been really strong. So we are very excited about the Prime program. We think it'll enter into a new chapter in India, and we've seen great success every country in the world that we've launched Prime, and we feel India is going to be no different. So we're looking forward to seeing what we can do on behalf of the Indian customer.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Victor, this is Darin. On Italy, yes, we continued to invest in Italy and really throughout Europe to keep pace with the strong customer demand we see. Since opening Italy in 2010, we've invested over EUR 450 million and created 1,700 jobs in Italy, and t
componenttext:
Victor, this is Darin. On Italy, yes, we continued to invest in Italy and really throughout Europe to keep pace with the strong customer demand we see. Since opening Italy in 2010, we've invested over EUR 450 million and created 1,700 jobs in Italy, and this increased investment will be to add future FC near Rome and other infrastructure assets. So, yes, this is really to support both the customers that we have there in Italy and throughout Europe, and we'll continue to invest in the coming years.
So thank you for joining the call today and for your questions. A replay will be available on our investor website at least through the end of the quarter. We appreciate your interest in Amazon.com and look forward to talking with you again next quarter. Thank you.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
