But the largest individual reasons for the ramp-up in investment between first half and second half of this year and also second half of this year versus last -- second half of last year are the things I mentioned on the call last quarter. First, video content and marketing associated with that is nearly doubling year-over-year in the second half of the year and continues to be a large increase both Q3 and Q4. In the quarter, in Q3, we added 18 fulfillment centers, and we've added 5 more in October. For the year, we'll add 26. Most of those are in North America, but that compares to 14 last year. And I would look -- looking back, there's a -- the last time we had double-digit increase in fulfillment centers was in 2012, when we added 11 in the third quarter. So it was a rare aggregation of start-ups in Q3 and Q4 that's helping us position better for Q4 volumes because paid unit growth continues to be strong, and Amazon fulfilled unit growth, which includes what we ship with FBA, is significantly higher than even that. So we are continuing to build for high AFN or Amazon-Fulfilled Network demand, including both retail and FBA. The number of warehouses that we added represents a 30% increase in square footage year-over-year. Last year, we increased square footage by just under 20%. The definition of square footage in this case is all of our warehouses plus our sortation and delivery centers. So it's pretty much our -- and customer service. So it's pretty much our full square footage that supports operations. So those will dissipate as we -- as they burn in. We've talked about fulfillment centers' initial start-up costs include increase in fixed costs but also variable costs as we train workers and also bring in inventory. And there's a number of transportation costs also related to the start-up of a new fulfillment center, both inbound and outbound. And they're inherently less efficient than more established, mature buildings. So there will be a cycle where those will be more productive next year than they are this year and more productive in 2018 than they are in 2017. So what you're seeing essentially in the second half of this year is the step-up in investment, primarily around digital content and also the fulfillment center investment, but also things like Echo and Alexa, which we're adding a lot of resources to, India and AWS as we add people there to support additional service at rapid growth in that business.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2. The first one, just to go back, Brian, the fulfillment build, past you talked about how it takes time to kind of get the fulfillment centers to peak efficiency. So with these new FCs opening, can you just talk about it? If you become more effici
componenttext: I have 2. The first one, just to go back, Brian, the fulfillment build, past you talked about how it takes time to kind of get the fulfillment centers to peak efficiency. So with these new FCs opening, can you just talk about it? If you become more efficient, so if you get into a lower volume quarter next year, there's less risk of deleverage? Or should we still kind of think about it's going to take time to get up to peak efficiency? Then the second one, AWS, Amazon as a company is very good at removing friction in the purchase process. Can you just talk about some of the main hurdles you still have to overcome for large enterprises to really start using AWS more?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So on the fulfillment network, as we build it, yes, they will be more productive next year than they are this holiday peak and probably even more productive in 2018. So I can't forecast it for you into next year quite yet, but we certainly had produ
componenttext: Sure. So on the fulfillment network, as we build it, yes, they will be more productive next year than they are this holiday peak and probably even more productive in 2018. So I can't forecast it for you into next year quite yet, but we certainly had productivity and additional costs at Q3 and even into Q4 this year as we build that space -- the additional capacity. Again, the underlying reason for that capacity build is the strength in paid units and even more so in the units that we're fulfilling, driven by our FBA program. The FBA program is the key pillar of our Prime offering. It adds selection. It makes Prime stronger. And then, that's a self-reinforcing loop where Prime then -- Prime's success attracts more sellers. So we're delighted to have that problem. We're just working very hard to get capacity in place and in productive use for Q4 and beyond.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Darin. On the AWS question, yes, we continue to invest in AWS on behalf of our customers. In addition to the technologies that make integrations easier, it helps companies move from an on-prem or a hybrid IT environment into AWS. We're going to co
componenttext: This is Darin. On the AWS question, yes, we continue to invest in AWS on behalf of our customers. In addition to the technologies that make integrations easier, it helps companies move from an on-prem or a hybrid IT environment into AWS. We're going to continue to do that. Specifically, things like the database migration tool that are helpful for customers when they move production databases to -- or from on-premises to the cloud with virtually no downtime. And also, many of our AWS customers are beginning to choose and continue to choose the AWS scheme and conversion tool which really switches database engines to get out of old guard proprietary databases and on to AWS. And so we'll continue to react to customer needs, and that will include opening up new regions. We've opened up Ohio this past quarter, and we've highlighted that we'll have another -- a number of regions coming online in a few months. So yes, we're doing a lot of things to help make it easier for all customers to migrate to AWS.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Hey, Brian, would you give us any commentary on 2 categories, in particular groceries and fashion and apparel? And particularly in groceries, I know you have released a couple of data points about Fresh rolling out into newer areas like Maryland. Gr
componenttext: Okay. Hey, Brian, would you give us any commentary on 2 categories, in particular groceries and fashion and apparel? And particularly in groceries, I know you have released a couple of data points about Fresh rolling out into newer areas like Maryland. Great to see that. But could you just talk about that on the investment horizon? Is that kind of moving the needle for you? And how big that in will you help us quantify how big that -- how big that already is to -- to the revenue growth that you're seeing, particularly on groceries? And any particular comments on fashion and apparel, same line of thinking.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, sure. Thanks, Mark. I will start with Fresh and groceries in general. So yes, this quarter, we launched in Northern Virginia, Maryland, Dallas and Chicago. We also launched a new pricing plan, which is the monthly $14.99 add-on to Prime in the U.S.
componenttext: Okay, sure. Thanks, Mark. I will start with Fresh and groceries in general. So yes, this quarter, we launched in Northern Virginia, Maryland, Dallas and Chicago. We also launched a new pricing plan, which is the monthly $14.99 add-on to Prime in the U.S. And we've expanded, as you know, previously into London. We're very happy with the progression, both in the geographies that we've been in for a long time, where we're continuing to add ZIP codes and additional neighborhoods, and also these new cities. Certainly a business where we continue to work on costs and profitability, but we are finding it a very attractive service to our customers, which is what we're after. Similarly, but not exactly the same as the Prime Now business, which has a similar overlap on things besides groceries. It's a slightly different model, obviously, where we're more about immediacy and a smaller list of items available in 1 to 2 hours. But there's certainly a lot of people who are using that for groceries and consumable items. And that is now up to 40 cities across 7 countries versus 17 this time last year. We're also adding restaurant, Amazon restaurant delivery, to the Prime Now offer in 19 metropolitan cities in the U.S. And that's up from 2 last year. So we continue to believe consumables, groceries are a key part of the offer to customers. And we are playing with very different models to see which works and for what needs. So we're very happy with the AmazonFresh. And we've now expanded quite a bit, as we've seen this year. And Prime Now, we're also very happy with, although obviously, the economics in that business are even tougher. But we do feel that our scale makes that possible because of our -- the geographic footprint and how close we are to customers.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, this is Darin. On fashion, fashion and apparel continue to be a large part of our EGM business and one that we're very excited about. We continue to make it easier for brands and manufacturers to come onboard in that category. We continue to work wi
componenttext: Mark, this is Darin. On fashion, fashion and apparel continue to be a large part of our EGM business and one that we're very excited about. We continue to make it easier for brands and manufacturers to come onboard in that category. We continue to work with the brands to come onboard, and we're happy with the traction we're seeing with those brands. And as we get more and more selection, we're really pleased with the customer engagement that we have there both from the discoverability, the technology that goes behind making it easier to shop fashion on our site, as well as the increased selection by adding the brand.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry. To answer your question about whether that's part of investment, yes, it's certainly part of our investment. But the larger ramp, if you will, in investment that we're seeing from the back end of last year and also the first half this year is m
componenttext: I'm sorry. To answer your question about whether that's part of investment, yes, it's certainly part of our investment. But the larger ramp, if you will, in investment that we're seeing from the back end of last year and also the first half this year is more related to digital content and building our fulfillment network, which I've already discussed.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mark May with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mark May with Citi.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: In some of these incremental investment areas like warehouses, logistics and also content, I know in some cases, you expensed upfront. In some cases, you amortize over time. Just wondering if you can give us a sense of how much of the recent step-up is ki
componenttext: In some of these incremental investment areas like warehouses, logistics and also content, I know in some cases, you expensed upfront. In some cases, you amortize over time. Just wondering if you can give us a sense of how much of the recent step-up is kind of being expensed? Particularly, looking at COGS as percent of retail revenues, which was up year-on-year for the first time in quite a while, how much of that was because of content that was expensed in the period? Just trying to kind of better understand that. I think also, you've been changing routing, and this is happening here shortly FBA pricing, including increasing your storage fees but also reducing your handling fees. I guess the question is, are these changes designed to just pass through kind of increasing shipping costs? Or is this more of a net neutral change, where really the goal is to try to free up capacity in some of your facilities?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me start with your second question on FBA. So yes, we did make some changes to the pricing formula for this holiday season. They're essentially meant to incent the right behavior among sellers around holiday. And the biggest issue we're trying to get
componenttext: Let me start with your second question on FBA. So yes, we did make some changes to the pricing formula for this holiday season. They're essentially meant to incent the right behavior among sellers around holiday. And the biggest issue we're trying to get out is having the most valuable products for holiday in the warehouse in those -- in the Prime space and not having the warehouse filled with things that may not sell until after the New Year. So we are trying to incentivize that behavior. We're also trying to incentivize getting inventory into the warehouse quicker. So yes, there the formulas were -- the changes to the pricing formulas were really with that in mind, to help the flow and the space utilization in Q4.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Darin. On the capitalization point, I'd say the things we capitalized are the core buildings and leasehold improvements in the buildings. But the things that we're seeing hit the P&L are the fixed and variable expenses that it takes to run the bui
componenttext: This is Darin. On the capitalization point, I'd say the things we capitalized are the core buildings and leasehold improvements in the buildings. But the things that we're seeing hit the P&L are the fixed and variable expenses that it takes to run the building. And I think that's what Brian is pointing out most pointedly in terms of what is impacting our -- the profitability of second half. So yes, the capitalization is relatively small in terms of -- other than the building itself.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Youssef Squali with Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Youssef Squali with Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: With the step up in investments and content from Prime Video, which you mentioned before, would you also be stepping up the international expansion? Maybe you can just remind us how many countries you're in with Prime Video, and whether there is a potenti
componenttext: With the step up in investments and content from Prime Video, which you mentioned before, would you also be stepping up the international expansion? Maybe you can just remind us how many countries you're in with Prime Video, and whether there is a potential chance of maybe stripping Prime Video from Prime to allow it to be expanded to other countries? And then do you -- I know you're not guiding to 2017, but just looking at the capacity increase that you had for FCs for 2016, should we expect kind of that as an ongoing kind of expense going forward? Or is the current buildup enough to maybe give you some spare capacity to cool that down for 2017?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So first, on your video comment, we're in 4 countries right now, the U.S., U.K., Germany and Japan, and we have stated that we will be in India soon. So the content that we are creating, especially through Amazon Studios, we are generally holding th
componenttext: Sure. So first, on your video comment, we're in 4 countries right now, the U.S., U.K., Germany and Japan, and we have stated that we will be in India soon. So the content that we are creating, especially through Amazon Studios, we are generally holding the worldwide rights to and can use that in other countries as well. And the cost of that then gets amortized to those countries. It will be part of the international segment results. So yes, we consider that to be very valuable as opposed to -- versus licensing many times by country the third-party rights to content that we don't create ourselves. Your question on fulfillment expenses, I can't extend the guidance into next year. So we will do that obviously at the end of next quarter, but I would say we are -- this was an extraordinary step-up, as I mentioned, in Q3 that is tied to very rapid growth in not only paid units, but Amazon-fulfilled units. So really, our forecast for additional capacity additions and the rate of additions will be tied to those growth factors as well. So we'll have to see. We right now are working on getting the capacity in. It was very lumpy this time. It was 18 warehouses in 1 quarter and another 5 in the first 3 weeks of the next quarter. So -- obviously, we'll be working on the efficiencies in all the warehouses we have, including the ones we just started up this year.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Colin Sebastian with Baird Equity Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Colin Sebastian with Baird Equity Research.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A follow-up on the FC question. And I guess more specifically, it sounds like you have enough capacity in terms of fulfillment centers for the holidays, but also wondering what your comfort level is in terms of your shipping partners to manage those deliv
componenttext: A follow-up on the FC question. And I guess more specifically, it sounds like you have enough capacity in terms of fulfillment centers for the holidays, but also wondering what your comfort level is in terms of your shipping partners to manage those deliveries. And then secondly, I was wondering how you would characterize the pricing environment for AWS, in particular, with more deep-pocketed competitors in the space now. Google, in fact, highlighted this in their conference call today.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me start with transportation. So yes, we are looking forward to a great holiday, and that includes working with our shipping partners both in the U.S. and globally. We've worked very closely with them to line up capacity, share capacity plans. W
componenttext: Sure. Let me start with transportation. So yes, we are looking forward to a great holiday, and that includes working with our shipping partners both in the U.S. and globally. We've worked very closely with them to line up capacity, share capacity plans. We certainly have additional delivery capability of our own. But with all of our partners, we work well in advance of the holiday to get our plans in place. We feel very confident. We're looking forward to a good holiday not only for customers but also for sellers. On your question on AWS, I didn't listen to the Google call, but -- you'll have to fill me in on that later. The thing I can tell you about pricing is that our pricing is -- price reductions are a core part of our philosophy, of course. We had a price decrease in Q3, and that was our 52nd since we started this business. So it's -- we are comfortable with price decreases. Not only do we lower the prices of our products, but we also create new services that are cheaper that customers can switch to. So they can also benefit from that as well. So if you step back and say, why do people choose AWS? I'll give you the points I said last quarter. Basically, what we hear are the functionality and pace of innovation is greater than our competition. We've added new, more new, significant features and services this year already than we had all of last year when we added 722. We have a partner and customer ecosystem. You've heard about the VMware deal that we signed this quarter. So we continue to extend with partners and build ecosystems that better support our customers. And finally, experience. We've been in this business a long time, longer than anyone else. And we've used that time to make our products and services better. So there was going to be a lot of winners in this space, as we said, but we are very happy with our position and the customer reception to our products.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Justin Post with Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Justin Post with Merrill Lynch.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess when you look at fourth quarter guidance and you back out AWS, it suggests that margins are, on the core business, are going to be pretty down versus last year. Do you view this as an abnormal investment cycle or just part of the overall kind of e
componenttext: I guess when you look at fourth quarter guidance and you back out AWS, it suggests that margins are, on the core business, are going to be pretty down versus last year. Do you view this as an abnormal investment cycle or just part of the overall kind of ebbs and flows of the business? And then long term, I know several years ago you talked about maybe high single digit, low double-digit margins long term. I wonder if you could refresh us on that. And also just let us know if you think international has structural margin differences than the U.S., the core retail business.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, as far as the continuation of investment into next year, I cannot give you much color on that today. What I can tell you again is that we've ramped up considerably. We've been investing quite openly in a lot of areas and continue to do so. We a
componenttext: Sure. Yes, as far as the continuation of investment into next year, I cannot give you much color on that today. What I can tell you again is that we've ramped up considerably. We've been investing quite openly in a lot of areas and continue to do so. We are experiencing a ramp-up, if you will, in the second half of this year, particularly tied again to AWS -- excuse me, the fulfillment center spend and also the video content spend. So we will continue to invest in video content. We'll continue to invest in fulfillment space to handle higher and higher paid unit volumes and shipped unit volumes. We'll continue to invest in things that we believe enhance the customer experience, particularly the Prime experience. Devices, we'll continue to invest in this, particularly Alexa and the Echo products. We'll continue to invest in getting faster and faster shipping methods for our consumers. We believe that's working. We're very happy with the results. We're very happy with the -- all the customers we have, but particularly the Prime customers that we have. As far as long-term operating margins, I can't forecast that right now. I can't forecast that for AWS business either. We are again working on 2 fronts. We are honing the businesses that we're in and making them as efficient and profitable as possible, while also investing very pointedly and very wisely, we believe, in things that will enhance customer experience and create lasting businesses for us down the line. We've said we want things that customers will love, that can grow to be large, will have strong financial returns and durable and can last for decades. So that's still our mission. We have pillars of the business right now with Marketplace, AWS and Prime, and we're actively looking for our fourth and fifth pillar.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering -- there have obviously been some headlines since the call that you did earlier with the press on the scale of this investment cycle relative to other investment cycles that you've been through. With the 2014 cycle sort of being the m
componenttext: I was just wondering -- there have obviously been some headlines since the call that you did earlier with the press on the scale of this investment cycle relative to other investment cycles that you've been through. With the 2014 cycle sort of being the most recent, how -- could you quantify a little bit more how you would compare this investment cycle to that most recent one? And to the extent that we are in the midst of this investment cycle, would you say we're in sort of the earlier or later stages? Any sort of clarity around that would be useful.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, yes. The word cycle, if I mentioned that, was an omission. It was a misspeak. The investment that we are seeing is a step-up versus what we have experienced in particularly the first half of this year and the last half, the second half of last year,
componenttext: Sure, yes. The word cycle, if I mentioned that, was an omission. It was a misspeak. The investment that we are seeing is a step-up versus what we have experienced in particularly the first half of this year and the last half, the second half of last year, which I mentioned. But we have said investments are going to be lumpy. They are going to be high sometimes, and they'll be moderate at other times. We are -- right now, the second half of this year looks like a big step-up compared to the first half, and it is. But again, it's all areas that we will continue to invest in, some of which I just actually went through a laundry list. So I would not characterize it as a cycle. I would characterize it as continued investments. We make investments with the idea that they are going to pay off, and they pay off in either directly in the business they're in or in their contribution to the total business many times as a part of the Prime program.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Blackledge with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Blackledge with Cowen and Company.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions. It seems you're increasing your efforts on the auto vertical, with the recent launch of Amazon Vehicles. Just wondering if you could discuss some of dynamics of the auto industry that make it attractive and maybe how it aligns with the P
componenttext: Just 2 questions. It seems you're increasing your efforts on the auto vertical, with the recent launch of Amazon Vehicles. Just wondering if you could discuss some of dynamics of the auto industry that make it attractive and maybe how it aligns with the Prime value prop. I'm also wondering if you had any plans to work directly with auto shops, just given your ability to service most areas in 1 to 2 days. And then just the second question. On grocery, would you consider physical locations in an effort to kind of expand and/or accelerate growth in that vertical?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Darin. On vehicles, Amazon Vehicles is really a car research destination and was built for the automotive community for customers. It gets information they need when shopping for vehicles off-site or shopping for parts and accessories on-site. And
componenttext: This is Darin. On vehicles, Amazon Vehicles is really a car research destination and was built for the automotive community for customers. It gets information they need when shopping for vehicles off-site or shopping for parts and accessories on-site. And the features include research tools, community engagement where you can talk to other customers. And certainly, we're trying to build a one-stop shop for vehicles, as an extension to the automotive store, which engages customers to add information about their cars and their garage, which makes it actually easier to shop for parts and accessories for your particular vehicle. And so we think there's a lot of opportunity there to add convenience for customers. On the B2B side, certainly, we do have the Amazon Business offering. Businesses of all shapes and sizes can sign up to be a B2B customer. And the selection that we have in our parts and automotive categories are certainly open to that channel. But I wouldn't speculate on anything we might do in a particular vertical for those Business customers.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And your comment -- your question on grocery and physical stores, I can't comment on any rumors and speculations there might be regarding that. But I will tell you is we have experimented with physical stores. As you may know, we have 3 physical boo
componenttext: Sure. And your comment -- your question on grocery and physical stores, I can't comment on any rumors and speculations there might be regarding that. But I will tell you is we have experimented with physical stores. As you may know, we have 3 physical bookstores, one in Seattle, one in San Diego and one in Portland; and 2 more coming, one in Boston and one in Chicago. And what we're finding is they're great places for customers to browse what ends up being a curated selection of books. And they also get to try out our devices, which is very beneficial. So they get to touch and try our e-readers, tablets, Fire TV and Echo. So we like what we see with that connection. And we also have pop-up stores that you may see and also college pickup points. So we will try different delivery methods or pickup points or ways of getting products to customers, but nothing specific to point out on the grocery side right now.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ben Schachter with Macquarie.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ben Schachter with Macquarie.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given the low unemployment rates that you're seeing in the US, do you expect any unusual impacts on wages for seasonal workers this year? And are you seeing overall wage pressure in the fulfillment centers? And then separately, if you can just talk about
componenttext: Given the low unemployment rates that you're seeing in the US, do you expect any unusual impacts on wages for seasonal workers this year? And are you seeing overall wage pressure in the fulfillment centers? And then separately, if you can just talk about trend lines you're seeing in paid units versus shipping units? Are they diverging meaningfully versus past?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so on wages, nothing to point out for this holiday. Our challenge, generally, is the volume of headcount that we're looking to hire, and we work well in advance with agencies to help to get seasonal employees. And many of them turn into full-time emp
componenttext: Yes, so on wages, nothing to point out for this holiday. Our challenge, generally, is the volume of headcount that we're looking to hire, and we work well in advance with agencies to help to get seasonal employees. And many of them turn into full-time employees after the holiday. So nothing specific on the wage pressure front. As you probably saw, our headcount is up 38% year-over-year in Q3. And that is a continuation of a lot of ops roles that are supporting the site to man the opening of the fulfillment centers we talked about, new Fresh locations, Prime Now. But also a lot of hiring in our tech areas, particularly around AWS and also the Echo, Alexa areas.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the second question?
componenttext: And the second question?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Sorry, go ahead. Okay. And our final question will come from the line of Neil Doshi with Mizuho.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just provide a little more color into the investment that you're making in India? What's driving that growth? And what stage is India in today relative to some of the other large international markets that you've launched in the past?
componenttext: Can you just provide a little more color into the investment that you're making in India? What's driving that growth? And what stage is India in today relative to some of the other large international markets that you've launched in the past?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So we are very encouraged by what we're seeing in India, but it is certainly very early on still. Most recent highlights would be the launch of the Prime program in India this past quarter. It's now one of the top-selling units on Amazon.in. An
componenttext: Yes, sure. So we are very encouraged by what we're seeing in India, but it is certainly very early on still. Most recent highlights would be the launch of the Prime program in India this past quarter. It's now one of the top-selling units on Amazon.in. And so it's very -- been well received by customers. It's hard to compare India to any other country. It's very different in its stage and structure. Being a third-party market has caused a lot of invention on our side. We're being creative. The team there in India has been very creative on whenever they find a roadblock or something that does not exist in another country, they create it themselves. Whether that's delivering stations to working with small merchants to -- you name it. So we're very happy with both of the customer engagement that we're seeing and also the seller engagement, which is very important in India, and very pleased with the team that runs it over there and the way they work with teams throughout the world.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Brian, to step back to Ben's other question on units, Ben, this is Darin. I will -- so paid units grew at 28% again this year, as it did in prior quarters. And as Brian pointed out earlier, our AFN units, our Amazon-Fulfilled units, which include our
componenttext:
And Brian, to step back to Ben's other question on units, Ben, this is Darin. I will -- so paid units grew at 28% again this year, as it did in prior quarters. And as Brian pointed out earlier, our AFN units, our Amazon-Fulfilled units, which include our first-party units as well as FBA units that go through our warehouses, are continuing -- are certainly higher than that 28%. And that's a result of the traction we're getting with our FBA subs.
So thank you for joining us on the call today and for your questions. A replay will be available on our Investor Relations website at least through the end of the quarter. We appreciate your interest in Amazon.com and look forward to talking with you again next quarter.
